questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a content of the region marked as ‘X’ in the diagram of perineum?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) External pudendal vessels

Explanation:

‘X’ depicts anal triangle; external pudendal vessels are not seen in this region.

Anal Triangle

Boundaries

Contents
  • Anterior: Posterior margin of the perineal membrane
  • Posterior: Coccyx
  • Posterolateral: Sacrotuberous ligament
  • Anal canal
  • Anal sphincter complex 
    • Internal anal sphincter
    • External anal sphincter
    • Puborectalis
  • Branches of the pudendal nerve 
  • Internal pudendal vessels.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs can be continued perioperatively?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) All of the above

 

Explanation:

 

Drug

Continued or stopped preoperatively

Antithyroid

Continued

Antiepileptic

Continued

Antidepressants

Continued

Smoking

Stop at least 6-8 weeks prior

Steroid

Continued

Anticonvulsants

Continued

Monoamine Oxidase Inhibitors (MAOIs)

Discontinue 2-3 weeks before surgery

Oral Contraceptive Pill

Discontinue at least 6 weeks before

Herbal Supplements

Discontinue at least 2 weeks before surgery

 

Note:

  • Ayurvedic medicine: Stop 2 weeks prior to surgery
  • All psychiatric meds continue except
    • Lithium: Stop 48 hrs before surgery
    • MAO Inhibitors/ TCA: Stop 3 Weeks Prior To Surgery

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presented with cough and breathing difficulty and was diagnosed with emphysema after radiographic examination. Which of the following genetic conditions should be suspected as a possible cause?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency

 

Explanation:

  • Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency is a genetic condition characterised by low levels or dysfunctional alpha-1 antitrypsin protein.

 

Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency:

  • It is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the alpha-1 antitrypsin gene located on Chromosome 14.
  • The condition primarily affects the lungs, leading to panacinar emphysema and the liver, causing cirrhosis due to abnormal protein accumulation.

 

Cystic fibrosis (Option A) is a genetic disorder caused by CFTR gene mutations, leading to thick mucus, chronic lung infections, and bronchiectasis.

  • While it causes obstructive lung disease, emphysema is not typical.

 

Asthma (Option B) is a chronic inflammatory condition causing reversible airway obstruction and episodic wheezing, coughing, and breathlessness.

  • It does not typically result in emphysema or structural lung damage.

 

Bronchiectasis (Option D) is a condition of permanently dilated bronchi due to chronic infections or inflammation.

  • While it causes cough and sputum production, it does not primarily lead to emphysema.

questions.text: Identify the given condition:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Marginal Placenta Previa

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows the edge of the placenta reaching up to the margin of the internal os but not covering it. This is known as marginal placenta previa.

 

Types of placenta previa:

Types of placenta previa 

Definitions

I

Low lying (Option D ruled out)

The placenta is implanted in the lower uterine segment but does not reach the internal os.

II

Marginal

The edge of the placenta is at the margin of the internal os.

III

Incomplete/partial central (Option B ruled out)

The placenta partially covers the internal os of the cervix.

IV

Central/complete (Option A ruled out)

The placenta completely covers the internal os of the cervix.

Revised Classification:

Types

Definitions

True Placenta previa

The placenta covers the internal os

Low lying placenta

The placenta lies within 2cm of internal is but does not cover it

questions.text: A study investigating the relationship between smoking and lung cancer found that the association was stronger in individuals who exercised less and weaker in those who exercised more. In this context, what role does exercise play?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Effect Modifier

Explanation:

Effect Modifier changes the strength or direction of the association between an exposure and an outcome. Here, exercise modifies the association between smoking and lung cancer, making it stronger in those who exercise less and weaker in those who exercise more.

 

Effect modifier:

  • It is a variable that differentially (positively and negatively) modifies the observed effect of a risk factor on disease status.
  • Features:
    • The magnitude of the effect of an exposure on the outcome will vary according to the presence of a third factor (effect modifier).
    • For effect modification, true relation must be there between the outcome(disease) and independent variable (risk factor).

questions.text: A patient presented with a hard mass over the right tibia, and subsequent imaging revealed the presence of sessile growth in the bone. Biopsy is done later, which shows the presence of “cartilage cap” over the lesion. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Osteochondroma

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation is suggestive of osteochondroma, characterised by the presence of cartilage cap over the lesion and sessile growth in the bone, which means the lesion has both bone and cartilage elements together.

 

Osteochondroma (Exostosis):

  • Osteochondroma is one of the most common benign bone tumors, also called exosurface.
  • It looks like a mushroom-like growth coming out of the bone and is in exact continuity with the underlying bone.
  • In osteochondroma, the tumor’s medulla is continuous with the bone medulla (inner part) and its cortex with the bone cortex (outer part), but it is covered by a cartilage cap, which distinguishes it and gives it the name osteochondroma.
  • Histology: It resembles a disorganized growth plate, and they undergo enchondral ossification, with the newly formed bone making up the inner portion of the head and stalk.

questions.text: A 28 y/o G3P2 woman at 39 weeks of gestation has just delivered via vaginal delivery. She has been diagnosed with severe anemia (Hb 8 g/dL). The obstetric team is concerned about the risk of PPH. What is the next best step in her management to prevent PPH?

choices.text: Administration of oxytocin infusion for at least one hour after delivery

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Administration of oxytocin infusion for at least one hour after delivery

 

Explanation:

Administration of oxytocin infusion for at least one hour after delivery is a crucial step in the active management of the third stage of labor, which can significantly reduce the incidence of PPH. Continuing oxytocin infusion helps maintain uterine contractions and reduces blood loss after delivery.

Prevention of PPH

Antenatal Measures

Intranatal Measures
  • Maintain hemoglobin > 10 g/dL (Option A)
  • Screen high-risk patients and deliver in well-equipped hospitals
  • Conduct blood grouping for all women
  • Localize the placenta in women with previous cesarean delivery using USG/MRI (Option C)
  • Plan delivery of women with morbidly adherent placenta by a senior obstetrician with blood products ready
  • Active management of the third stage of labor
  • Continue oxytocin infusion for at least one hour after delivery in induced/augmented labor
  • Administer oxytocin 5 IU slow IV during cesarean section (Option B)
  • Use Carbetocin (100 μg IV over 1 min.) to prevent PPH
  • Check the uterovaginal canal for trauma after a difficult labor or instrumental delivery
  • Observe for two hours post-delivery to ensure uterus contraction before transferring to the ward
  • Prefer local or epidural anesthesia over general anesthesia in forceps, ventouse, or breech delivery
  • Allow spontaneous placental separation during cesarean section to reduce blood loss
  • Examine the placenta and membranes routinely for completeness

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with a history of recurrent headaches. She describes a severe throbbing headache on the right side of her head associated with nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light and sound. She has tried over-the-counter pain relievers without relief. Triptans are being considered. Which of the following is the fastest-acting oral triptan?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Rizatriptan

Explanation:

  • Rizatriptan has the fastest onset of action among oral triptans and it is useful for acute migraine attacks requiring rapid relief.
  • The onset of relief begins within 30 minutes, which is quicker than other oral triptans.
  • It is highly lipophilic, allowing faster blood-brain barrier penetration.

questions.text: Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) like Face shields, goggles, gloves and hazmat suits are disposed of in which colour bin?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Red

Explanation:

Most personal protective equipment (PPE), like shoe covers, head covers, disposable linen gowns, and masks, is disposed of in a yellow bag, whereas face shields, goggles, gloves, and hazmat suits are disposed in a red bag as they are considered infected plastic waste.

 

Category

Type of BMW

Nature of Treatment

Yellow
  • Used masks, headcovers/caps, shoe covers, disposable linen gowns
  • Waste contaminated with body/body fluids of COVID-19 patients.
  • Incineration/plasma pyrolysis or deep burial.

Red

  • PPE such as goggles, face shields, splash proof aprons, plastic coveralls, Hazmat suits, nitrile gloves.
  • Autoclaving or microwaving/hydroclaving, and then sent for recycling (not to landfill).

White
  • White sharps, including metals.
  • Auto or dry heat sterilization followed by shredding and mutilation or encapsulation.

Blue
  • Glassware, metallic body implants.
  • Disinfection or autoclaving/microwaving, hydroclaving and then sent to recycling.

questions.text: A 60-year-old diabetic patient presents with worsening vision. Fundoscopy reveals retinal edema, microaneurysms, and hard exudates. Which of the following mechanisms is not responsible for the development of diabetic retinopathy?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Reduced blood viscosity

Explanation: 

Reduced blood viscosity is not a contributing factor to diabetic retinopathy; instead, increased blood viscosity is observed.

  • Diabetic Retinopathy develops due to:
    • Cellular damage: From sorbitol, AGEs, Protein kinase C activation, oxidative stress (Option A)
    • Hematological-biochemical changes: Increased blood viscosity (Option B), platelet adhesiveness, and altered lipids 
    • Microangiopathy: Breakdown of the inner blood-retinal barrier (Option D), capillary damage 
    • Neovascularization: ​​​​​​​​​​​​​​Driven by increased proangiogenic factors​​​​​​​ (Option C)like VEGF and PDGF, with reduced anti-angiogenic protection.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with a history of mild fever and a rash. The rash began with red, flushed cheeks, as shown in the image below and has now developed into a lacy, reticular pattern on the arms and legs. The child has no significant respiratory symptoms or joint pain. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Fifth disease

 

Explanation:

The clinical presentation and image depicting rash, starting with a "slapped cheek" appearance and progressing to a lacy, reticular pattern, is characteristic of the fifth disease, or erythema infectiosum, caused by parvovirus B19.

Clinical features of erythema infectiosum
  • Prodromal phase: Low-grade fever, headache, and mild upper respiratory tract infection symptoms.
  • The characteristic rash in this condition is a "slapped cheek appearance”, presenting as erythematous flushing on the face.
  • The erythematous rash spreads to the trunk and proximal extremities as a lacy or reticulated pattern.


 

 

First disease (Option A) is another name for Measles / Rubeola, an exanthematous illness caused by an RNA virus belonging to the paramyxovirus family. Here, fever occurs before the onset of rash.

Second disease (Option B) is scarlet fever, which is characterised by fever and an erythematous rash along with strawberry tongue, caused by Group A βStreptococcus.

Sixth disease (Option D) is also known as Roseola infantum or erythema subitum, in which a rash appears once the fever disappears. It is commonly caused by human herpes virus (HHV)-6 and less commonly by HHV-7 and echovirus 16.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient with a history of recurrent renal stones is scheduled for laser-based intracorporeal lithotripsy to treat a 2 cm stone in the renal pelvis. Which of the following lasers is most commonly used for intracorporeal lithotripsy procedures?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Holmium: YAG laser

Explanation:

The Holmium: YAG laser is the most commonly used laser for intracorporeal lithotripsy as it is highly effective in fragmenting stones and is widely used for treating both renal and ureteral stones.

Types of Intracorporeal Lithotripsy

Description

Laser Lithotripsy
  • Holmium: YAG laser
  • Used in Renal stones and BPH
  • Stone vaporization by photo-thermal mechanism
  • Costly but safe

Electrohydraulic Lithotripsy (EHL)
  • Cheap but low safety margin
  • Mainly used for bladder stones

Ultrasonic Lithotripsy
  • Not commonly used

Ballistic Lithotripsy
  • Not commonly used

questions.text:
Match each structure of the Orthomyxovirus (Influenza Virus) with its corresponding function.


	
		
			
			1. Hemagglutinin (HA)
			
			
			A) Forms ion channels in the envelope
			
		
		
			
			2. Neuraminidase (NA)
			
			
			B) Responsible for RNA transcription and replication
			
		
		
			
			3. Polymerase proteins (PB1, PB2, PA)
			
			
			C) Aids in viral release and prevents virion aggregation
			
		
		
			
			4. Nucleoprotein
			
			
			D) Binds sialic acid receptors for viral entry
			
		
		
			
			5. Matrix protein - M1
			
			
			E) Forms a shell beneath the envelope
			
		
		
			
			6. Matrix protein - M2
			
			
			F) Forms a ribonucleoprotein complex with viral RNA
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 1-D, 2-C, 3-B, 4-F, 5-E, 6-A

 

Explanation:

 

1. Hemagglutinin (HA)

D) Binds sialic acid receptors for viral entry

2. Neuraminidase (NA)

C) Aids in viral release and prevents virion aggregation

3. Polymerase proteins (PB1, PB2, PA)

B) Responsible for RNA transcription and replication

4. Nucleoprotein

F) Forms a ribonucleoprotein complex with viral RNA

5. Matrix protein - M1

E) Forms a shell beneath the envelope

6. Matrix protein - M2

A) Forms ion channels in the envelope

questions.text:
Match the following species of Treponema with the respective diseases they cause.

 


	
		
			
			1. Treponema pallidum
			
			
			I. Pinta
			
		
		
			
			2. Treponema endemicum
			
			
			II. Venereal syphillis
			
		
		
			
			3. Treponema pertenue
			
			
			III. Yaws
			
		
		
			
			4. Treponema carateum
			
			
			IV. Endemic syphillis (Bejel)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 1-II; 2-IV; 3-III; 4-I

Explanation:

 

  • Treponema pallidum: The causative organism of Venereal syphilis.
    • It is generally acquired by close sexual contact.
  • Treponema pertenue: Causes yaws.
    • It is acquired via skin-to-skin contact.
  • Treponema carateum: Causes pinta.
    • It is acquired via skin-to-skin contact.
  • Treponema endemicium: Causes endemic syphilis.
    • It is acquired via kissing.

questions.text: Person presented to ED with complaints of severe chest pain for 1 hour. CT chest done revealed the presence of Aortic dissection. Patient was taken up for an emergency endovascular surgery without obtaining consent as there were no caregivers present at the time of presentation. Patient succumbed to hypotensive shock during the procedure. The surgeon will not be held liable under which legal provision?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) BNS 30

Explanation:

  • Aortic dissection is a surgical emergency without which the patient would die, and does not warrant an obtained consent under emergency circumstances, and so the Surgeon will not be held liable for any unforeseen consequences during/after the procedure under BNS 30.
  • This is known as the Doctrine of Anticipation.

 

BNS 25
  • Act not intended to cause death/grievous hurt done by a person >18 years of age after rightful consent.

BNS 26 (Option A)
  • Act done in good faith for a person’s benefit after obtaining lawful consent.

BNS 27 (Option B)
  • Act done in good faith for the benefit of a child (<12 years) or a person with unsound mind with guardian’s consent

BNS 28 (Option C)
  • Consent given by a person under fear or threat/under misconception of fact/child under 12 years of age/person of unsound mind/under intoxicated state is considered invalid.

BNS 30 (Option D)
  • An act done in good faith for the benefit of a person without their consent is not an offense.
  • This is true if the circumstances make it impossible for the person to give consent.
  • Known as Doctrine of Anticipation.

questions.text:
Match the following images with their distinguishing features

 


	
		
			
			1)

			
			
			
			a) Benign capillary malformation
			
		
		
			
			2)

			
			
			
			b) Contains eosinophils
			
		
		
			
			3)

			
			
			
			c) Contains melanocytes
			
		
		
			
			4)

			
			
			
			d) Contains keratin
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 1-d, 2-c, 3-a, 4-b

 

Explanation:

 

Condition

Features

Milia

 Small (≈3 mm), benign, white keratin-filled cysts are commonly found on the face and nose.

Mongolian Spots/ Dermal melanocytosis

 Slate-blue patches on the back/buttocks due to dermal melanocytes are common in Black, Asian, and Native American infants.
Benign, usually fades within 1 year.

Stork bites/ Salmon Patch/ Angel kiss
  • The benign capillary malformation can appear as flat red patches on a newborn's forehead and upper eyelids.
  • Do not need treatment because they are harmless and will fade over time.

Erythema toxicum neonatorum

 Small white papules on a red base, appearing 1–3 days after birth, benign and lasts about a week, seen on face, torso, and limbs.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with episodes of severe headaches, palpitations, and sweating. Imaging reveals a large adrenal mass and biochemical tests confirm elevated plasma metanephrines. Further genetic testing shows a mutation in the SDHB gene. Which of the following genetic syndromes is most likely associated with her condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Hereditary Paraganglioma-Pheochromocytoma Syndromes (HPPS)

 

Explanation:

The presence of an SDHB gene mutation, along with symptoms of severe headaches, palpitations, sweating, imaging showing a large adrenal mass, and elevated plasma metanephrines, is most consistent with Hereditary Paraganglioma-Pheochromocytoma Syndrome (HPPS).

  • It encompasses germline mutations in several genes, including SDH subunits.
  • SDHB mutations are particularly noted for their association with high rates of malignant pheochromocytomas and extra-adrenal tumors.
    • These mutations lead to the accumulation of Krebs cycle intermediates, promoting tumorigenesis.
  • Patients with SDHB mutations are at high risk for malignant extra-adrenal (abdominal or thoracic) tumors, making it the most likely syndrome in this clinical scenario.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male, with past h/o cholesterol stones, presents with intermittent right upper quadrant pain and occasional nausea.USG reveals the gallbladder mucosa has a coarse, granular appearance with small nodules and some larger polypoid formations. On performing laparoscopic cholecystectomy of this patient, the following appearance of the gall bladder was observed. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Cholesterolosis

Explanation:

These specific ultrasound findings and the specimen along with the association with cholesterol stones are characteristic of Strawberry Gallbladder (Cholesterolosis).

  • Accumulation of lipids (triglycerides, cholesterol precursors, and cholesterol esters) in the gallbladder mucosa.
  • Appearance:
    • Nodules <1 mm in diameter in about two-thirds of cases, giving the mucosa a coarse, granular look.
    • Remaining one-third of cases - Nodules are larger and polypoid (polypoid form).
    • Yellow lipid deposits on a hyperaemic mucosa background create the ‘strawberry gallbladder’ appearance
    • Might be associated with cholesterol stones.
  • Management: Laparoscopic cholecystectomy in symptomatic patients.

Acute cholecystitis (Option A): Typically presents with more acute symptoms, such as severe right upper quadrant pain, fever, and leukocytosis, without the specific ultrasound appearance described.

Porcelain gallbladder (Option B): Characterized by extensive calcium encrustation of the gallbladder wall, giving a bluish, brittle appearance, not mentioned in the scenario.

Gallbladder carcinoma (Option D): Typically associated with more serious symptoms and imaging findings of masses or irregular thickening, not specifically described in this scenario.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a content in the 4th compartment of extensor retinaculum?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Extensor pollicis brevis

 

Explanation:

  • Extensor pollicis brevis is in the 1st compartment of the extensor retinaculum.
  • Extensor Retinaculum: Thickened deep fascia on the back of the wrist. It is divided into 6 compartments. 
Compartment of Extensor Retinaculum Structure(s)
I
  • Abductor pollicis longus
  • Extensor pollicis brevis
II
  • Extensor carpi radialis longus
  • Extensor carpi radialis brevis
III
  • Extensor pollicis longus
IV
  • Extensor digitorum
  • Extensor indicis
  • Posterior interosseous nerve
  • Anterior interosseous artery
V
  • Extensor digiti minimi
VI
  • Extensor carpi ulnaris

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with an incidental finding of a renal mass on imaging. The mass shows an enhancing appearance on cross-sectional imaging with a central stellate scar. A biopsy is inconclusive, and the mass is surgically removed. Histopathological examination reveals granular, eosinophilic cytoplasm within the tumor cells, negative for cytokeratin 7. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Renal Oncocytoma

Explanation:

  • Renal Oncocytoma is characterized by granular, eosinophilic cytoplasm due to abundant mitochondria (oncocytes).
  • The enhancing mass with a central stellate scar is the suggestive feature.
     

Renal Oncocytoma

Definition & Prevalence
  • Benign renal tumor with oncocytes, characterized by granular, eosinophilic cytoplasm.

Diagnosis
  • CECT: (Investigation of choice): Presents as an enhancing mass
    • Central Stellate Scarring (star-shaped scar within the tumor).
    • Spoke Wheel Appearance.

 

Clear Cell Renal Cell Carcinoma (Option A) typically has cells with clear cytoplasm due to the loss of lipids, and it does not commonly present with a central scar.

Chromophobe Renal Cell Carcinoma (Option C) usually lacks the central stellate scar and has a different histological appearance with more distinct cell borders and perinuclear halos, staining positive for cytokeratin 7.

Papillary Renal Cell Carcinoma (Option D) often has a papillary architecture and cells with more foamy or pale cytoplasm, and the presence of a central scar is not typical.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman with end-stage renal disease recently received a compatible donor organ from her brother. The kidney transplant surgery proceeds as planned, but within minutes of reperfusion, the kidney becomes mottled, cyanotic and anuric. What is the cause for this presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Preformed antibodies in the recipient

Explanation:

  • The given clinical scenario suggests hyperacute graft rejection due to preformed antibodies in the recipient.

Hyperacute Graft Rejection

  • Hyperacute Graft Rejection is the most rapid and catastrophic form of graft rejection, occurring immediately on the operating table or within the first 48 hours of transplantation.
  • Pathogenesis: Hyperacute rejection is caused by preformed circulating IgG antibodies against donor antigens (mainly HLA or ABO), which may arise from prior pregnancies, multiple blood transfusions, or previous organ transplants.
  • Mechanism: Preformed antibodies bind to donor endothelial antigens, activating complement and causing widespread thrombosis, vascular occlusion, ischemia, and graft necrosis, leading to a kidney that rapidly becomes cyanotic, flaccid, and anuric (sometimes with a few drops of blood).
  • Clinical features: Hyperacute rejection presents with a mottled blue ischemic kidney, loss of graft tone, and absent urine output (anuria) or occasionally hematuria (few drops of blood).
  • Immunologically, hyperacute rejection represents a Type II hypersensitivity reaction mediated by antibodies.

questions.text: A 50-year-old immunocompromised patient presents with cough, fever, weight loss, hepatosplenomegaly, and lymphadenopathy. She recently cleaned an old barn where she was exposed to large amounts of bird droppings. On examination, she has mild tachycardia, and her lungs exhibit scattered crackles. A chest X-ray reveals patchy infiltrates and several calcified nodules. Histopathology and a lactophenol cotton blue (LPCB) mount of cultured colonies are provided. What treatment is she started on?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Amphotericin-B 

 

Explanation:

  • Based on the patient’s history, histopathology showing intramacrophagic yeast form and (LPCB) mount showing numerous hyaline hyphae with few tuberculate macroconidia (arrows) and many smooth-walled oval microconidia are pointing towards a diagnosis of disseminated histoplasmosis.

Histoplasmosis

Diagnosis

Microscopy:

  • Stained smears of the specimens show small intra- and extracellular yeast cells
 

Culture:

  • Blood agar and Sabouraud agar show characteristic growth
  • White, cottony, mycelial growth with large, thick-walled, spherical spores with tuberculate (finger-like projections)
 

Serodiagnosis:

  • Antibody titers increase in progressive disease
  • Antigen tests on urine and serum are helpful for immunocompromised individuals.

Skin Test:

  • Delayed hypersensitivity to histoplasmin confirms exposure

Treatment

Amphotericin-B (Option B) for two to four weeks, followed by a year of itraconazole (Option A ruled out)

Fluconazole (Option C ruled out): It is usually reserved for less severe infections or maintenance therapy after initial treatment with more potent antifungals like amphotericin-B. 

Surgical resection (Option D ruled out): It may be considered for localised infections or complications like abscesses, but it is not appropriate as a primary treatment strategy for disseminated histoplasmosis.

questions.text: A 34-year-old female presents with neck swelling and a history of childhood neck irradiation for Hodgkin’s lymphoma. On examination, a hard mass is found in the neck. FNAC confirms thyroid carcinoma with HPE image given below, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Papillary thyroid carcinoma

Explanation:

The clinical scenario suggests Papillary Thyroid Carcinoma, which is common in the 3rd to 4th decade and often follows childhood irradiation.

  • Origin: Follicular cells
  • Genetics: BRAF, RET-PTC
  • Risk factors: 
    • Radiation
    • Thyroglossal cyst
    • Hashimoto’s thyroiditis
  • Clinical Manifestations: 
    • Seen in the 3rd to 4th decade.
    • Midline swelling in the anterior part of the neck
    • Occasionally, lateral aberrant thyroid is seen.
    • Metastasis: Lymphatic
  • Characteristic histological features include:
    • Papillary projections
    • Optically clear nuclei (Orphan Annie eye nuclei)
    • Pseudo-inclusion bodies
    • Psammoma bodies (Dystrophic calcification).

Follicular thyroid carcinoma (Option A): Less associated with radiation exposure and spreads hematogenously; HPE shows follicular cell architecture with capsular and/or vascular invasion, but lacks the nuclear features of papillary carcinoma.

Medullary thyroid carcinoma (Option B): Arises from parafollicular C-cells, not follicular cells, and is associated with MEN 2 and elevated calcitonin; HPE shows nests or sheets of polygonal cells with amyloid stroma (Congo red positive).

Anaplastic thyroid carcinoma (Option C): Highly aggressive tumor seen in the elderly, not young adults; HPE shows undifferentiated pleomorphic giant cells and spindle cells with high mitotic activity and necrosis, lacking any features of differentiated thyroid cancer.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with chronic GERD undergoes endoscopy, which shows a 3 cm segment of salmon-colored mucosa above the gastroesophageal junction. Biopsy confirms intestinal metaplasia without dysplasia, and no nodularity or ulceration is seen.What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: High-dose proton pump inhibitor (PPI) therapy and aspirin

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) High-dose proton pump inhibitor (PPI) therapy and aspirin

Explanation:

Endoscopy findings are consistent with Barrett’s Esophagus - High-dose PPI therapy can reduce acid reflux and allow for mucosal healing, while aspirin has been shown to have a chemopreventive effect (combination can improve outcomes).

  • Treatment:
    • Treat underlying GERD, same pharmacological therapy as symptomatic GERD
    • Chemoprevention: Aspirin + high-dose PPI improves outcomes (Option C)
    • Dysplastic Treatment: Ablate/resect without invasive cancer, controversial in non-dysplastic
    • Ablative Therapy: Flat lesions only, RFA preferred
    • EMR vs ESD
      • EMR: easier, piecemeal;
      • ESD: en bloc, better margins
  • Post-Treatment: Surveillance for recurrence/persistent Barrett's or neoplasia

 

​​​​​​​

questions.text: Which of the following is the IV induction agent of choice in a patient with decompensated Cirrhosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Propofol

Explanation:

Propofol is the IV induction agent of choice in patients with hepatic disease because it has a rapid onset and shorter recovery time, making it safer for these patients.

 

Anesthesia for patients with hepatic diseases:

  • IV induction agent of choice: Propofol
  • Muscle relaxants of choice: Cis-atracurium/Atracurium due to organ-independent Hoffman degradation (do not rely on renal or hepatic clearance)
  • Inhalational agent: Desflurane or Isoflurane, or Sevoflurane
  • Avoid using halothane: Risk of halothane-induced hepatitis
  • Narcotics used: Fentanyl, Sufentanil
  • Sedatives used: Oxazepam, Lorazepam
  • All long-acting narcotics and sedatives should be avoided in Cirrhotic patients.

Thiopentone (Option A): Prolonged recovery in liver disease.

Etomidate (Option C): Hemodynamically stable but not first choice.

Ketamine (Option D): Increases secretions and may worsen encephalopathy.

questions.text: Sudden shrinkage of brain cells in acute hypernatremia encountered in neonate on day 2 of life can lead to development of:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Intra-parenchymal bleeding:

  • Hypernatremia increases osmolality of the ECF generating an osmotic gradient between the ECF and ICF. Hence water shifts out of brain cells causing cell shrinkage. This osmotic shift can cause tearing of cerebral vessels causing intracerebral / intraparenchymal haemorrhage.

Incorrect Options:

  • Osmotic demyelination syndrome (ODS) occurs with rapid correction of hyponatremia, not hypernatremia.
  • Paralytic ileus is seen with hypokalemia and tachyarrhythmias are seen due to variation in potassium levels.

questions.text: A 35 year old female hiker ascends to 5,000m in 2 days. Within 24 hours, she develops severe headaches, nausea, coordination difficulties, confusion, and occasional hallucinations. On examination, she is ataxic, with a GCS score of 10 and signs of papilledema. What is the next best step in managing this patient?

choices.text: Immediate descent to a lower altitude and start oxygen therapy.
Start dexamethasone and monitor for improvement
Provide hydration, antiemetics, and continue the ascent
Administer acetazolamide and maintain current altitude for the next 24 hours at least.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Immediate descent to a lower altitude and start dexamethasone

Explanation:

The patient’s signs and symptoms are suggestive of a condition known as High-altitude cerebral edema (HACE).

  • Immediate descent to a lower altitude is the most crucial step in the management of HACE to reduce hypoxic stress.
  • Starting dexamethasone can help reduce cerebral edema and inflammation, complementing the descent.

 

  • Oxygen therapy (Option B) can provide temporary symptomatic relief, but it does not address the need for reducing cerebral hypoxia and edema.
  • While hydration and antiemetics (Option C) can provide symptomatic relief, continuing the ascent is highly dangerous in the context of severe HACE.
  • Acetazolamide is useful for preventing and treating mild to moderate altitude sickness, but it is not sufficient as a standalone treatment for severe HACE.
    • Maintaining the current altitude can worsen the patient’s condition (Option D).

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with a 12-day history of missed periods and a positive pregnancy test undergoes a procedure to empty her uterus. Identify the instrument used in this early pregnancy management procedure:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Menstrual regulation syringe

Explanation:

The instrument shown above is a menstrual regulation syringe.    

Aspect

Manual Vacuum Aspiration (MVA)
(Option B)

Menstrual Regulation (Option D)

Use

Uterine evacuation up to 12 weeks of pregnancy for medical termination.

Aspiration of endometrial cavity within 14 days of missed period in a woman with a previous normal cycle.

Instrument used

MVA Syringe: Has double pinchable valves

MR Syringe: Has a single pinchable valve

Anesthesia

Local anesthesia

Sedation or paracervical block

Indications

Medical termination of pregnancy, incomplete/missed abortion, molar pregnancy, blighted ovum, endometrial sampling/biopsy.

Missed period, failed abortion, molar pregnancy, ectopic pregnancy exclusion.

Uterine curette (Option A): Commonly used in D&C, a method for uterine evacuation, it is more invasive and typically used in later stages of pregnancy or for different indications.

Karman Cannula (Option C) is a component used in the MVA procedure but does not function independently as the evacuation instrument.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a symptom of Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD)?

choices.text: Avoidance of reminders related to the trauma
Intense feelings of guilt and fear

questions.solution:
Answer: D) Increased sleepiness

Explanation:

Insomnia is more commonly seen in PTSD rather than an increase in sleepiness.

 

Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder: stress disorder occurring after a traumatic event that may be exposure to actual or threatened death, serious injury, or sexual violence and symptoms occurs for a month or more.

Acute Stress Disorder : Trauma-related symptoms (e.g. fear, helplessness) lasting 3 days to 1 month, similar to PTSD.

Symptoms of Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD)

  • Mood (Option C ruled out)
    • Negative feelings like fear, guilt, and anger
  • Avoidance (Option B ruled out)
    • Avoiding people, places, or objects that relate to the traumatic event
    • Social withdrawal
  • Hyperarousal (Option D)
    • Hypervigilant
    • Poor sleep
    • Exaggerated startle response
    • Poor concentration
  • Intrusive symptoms
    • Flashbacks (Option A ruled out)
    • Dreams and memories
    • Distressing re-experiencing of the traumatic event

questions.text: Which of the following is a pre-sinusoidal cause of portal hypertension?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Schistosomiasis

Explanation:

Schistosomiasis is one of the pre-sinusoidal intrahepatic Causes of Portal Hypertension.

  • Pre-sinusoidal
    • Extrahepatic
      • Portal vein thrombosis
      • Splenic vein thrombosis
      • Myelofibrosis
      • Arterioportal shunt
      • Tropical splenomegaly
    • Intrahepatic
      • Schistosomiasis
      • Congenital hepatic fibrosis
      • Portal infiltration (e.g., sarcoidosis)
      • Drugs and toxins
  • Sinusoidal
    • ​​​​​​​Cirrhosis (Option A ruled out)
  • Post-sinusoidal​​​​​​​​​​​​​​
    • Hepatic vein occlusion: Budd-Chiari syndrome (Option B ruled out)
    • Veno-occlusive disease
    • Congestive cardiac failure (Option C ruled out)

 

​​​​​​​

questions.text:
An 80-year-old female patient came with complaints of gradual progressive diminution of vision for 2 years in both her eyes. She reports that over the last year, she noticed an improvement in her ability to read without glasses. The following finding is seen on slit lamp examination over the right eye and the left eye has similar opacity.



Choose the most appropriate course of management for this patient.

choices.text: Advise lifestyle modification and review after 3 months.
Recommend corticosteroids eye drops and reassess in 6 months.
Prescribe her rigid gas-permeable contact lenses.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Plan for Phacoemulsification.

Explanation:

Gradual, progressive loss of vision along with improvement in near vision (referred to as “second sight”), combined with characteristic slit-lamp findings, is suggestive of Nuclear Cataract, for which phacoemulsification is the treatment of choice.

  • Management:
    • Surgical measures: Mainstay of treatment.
    • Cataract surgeries:
      • ICCE (not preferred now)
      • ECCE
      • SICS (Small Incision Cataract Surgery)
      • Phacoemulsification (most preferred)
    • Followed by IOL implantation: PC-IOL (Posterior chamber-intraocular lens) is preferred.

Advise lifestyle modification and review after 3 months (Option A) would not address the cataract directly and would not improve the visual acuity.

Recommend corticosteroids eye drops and reassess in 6 months (Option B): The use of topical corticosteroids after cataract surgery reduces postoperative noninfectious inflammation but it is not used as the treatment for nuclear cataract.

Prescribe her rigid gas-permeable contact lenses (Option D): Rigid gas-permeable contact lenses are indicated for early-stage keratoconus with astigmatism.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presented with complaints of severe morning headache associated with nausea, vomiting and seizure. On examination, the doctor suspected a brain tumour and suggested an MRI, which revealed a tumour at the vermis region. Which of the following syndromes is associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Turcot’s syndrome

 

Explanation:

  • The above features suggest Medulloblastoma, the most common type of primitive neuroectodermal tumour (PNET) and the most common malignant pediatric brain tumour.
  • It predominantly occurs in the first decade of life, with a second peak around age 30.
  • Histology: Characterized by densely packed small round cells with large nuclei and scant cytoplasm.
  • Location: Typically found in the cerebellum (vermis) in children and the lateral cerebellar hemisphere in adults.
  • Clinical Presentation: Symptoms include headache, vomiting, nausea, weakness, papilledema, and ataxia.
  • Diagnosis: MRI is used for imaging.
  • Management: Treatment involves surgical resection followed by radiotherapy and chemotherapy.
  • Association: Medulloblastoma is associated with Turcot's syndrome.

questions.text: A 62-year-old patient presents with difficulty seeing objects in the right half of the visual field in both eyes. Based on this clinical presentation, which of the following is the most likely location of the lesion affecting the visual pathway?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Left Optic tract

 

Explanation:

The clinical presentation of difficulty seeing objects in the right half of the visual field (nasal from the left field and temporal from the right field ) in both eyes indicates a visual field defect known as Right Homonymous Hemianopia, which occurs due to a defect in the Left Optic Tract (lesion posterior to the optic chiasma) affecting fibers from the right visual field of both eyes. The left optic tract carries these fibers (left temporal + right nasal retina).

 

Visual Pathway:

  • Temporal fibers carry impulses from the Nasal field, and Nasal fibres carry the Temporal field.


  • Left optic nerve (Option A): Optic nerve lesion → monocular vision loss.

  • Optic chiasma(Option B)→ bitemporal hemianopia.

  • Right Lateral Geniculate Body (Option D)The lateral geniculate body is rarely isolated.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with type 2 diabetes is started on evaluation for incretin-based therapy to improve postprandial glycemic control. His physician explains that certain gastrointestinal hormones enhance insulin secretion from pancreatic beta cells after a meal. Which of the following GI hormones is not responsible for insulin secretion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) VIP

 

Explanation:

  • VIP mainly causes smooth muscle relaxation, vasodilation, and increased intestinal secretion, but it does not directly stimulate insulin secretion.

  • GLP-1 (Option A) and GIP (Option B) are incretins that enhance insulin release after nutrient intake.

  • CCK (Option D) has a weak insulinotropic effect, especially in the presence of glucose.

 

GI Hormones associated with the secretion of insulin from the pancreas:

 

HORMONE

STIMULI

CELLS

GIP (Gastric inhibitory peptide)

(A.k.a Glucose-dependent insulinotropic peptide)

Protein, Fats, Carbohydrates.


 

K cells of duodenum and jejunum.

Glucagon-like peptide

L cells in the small intestine.

CCK

Protein, Fats, Acid

I cells in duodenum and jejunum.

questions.text:
In a recent census survey conducted in a developing country, the government aims to measure the literacy levels among its population accurately. The survey team decides to calculate both the crude literacy rate and the effective literacy rate to gain a comprehensive understanding.

What distinguishes the effective literacy rate from the crude literacy rate?

choices.text: It provides a broad measure of literacy across all age groups.
It focuses on the population aged 7 years and above.
The literacy rate is calculated using the total population as the denominator.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) It focuses on the population aged 7 years and above.

Explanation: The Effective Literacy Rate focuses on the population aged 7 years and above.

Crude Literacy Rate

Effective Literacy Rate

Definition: The literacy rate is calculated using the total population as the denominator. (Option C)

Definition: The literacy rate is calculated using the population aged 7 years and above as the denominator.

Includes the entire population. (Option D)

Focuses on the population aged 7 years and above.

Provides a broad measure of literacy across all age groups. (Option A)

Offers a more specific measure of literacy among individuals more likely to have completed basic education.

questions.text: A 45 year old woman presents to a Community Health Center (CHC) with a persistent cough, fever, and night sweats for the past three weeks. She has significant weight loss and a known history of contact with a TB patient. The clinician suspects TB and aims to confirm the diagnosis. According to NTEP guidelines, which of the following diagnostic modalities is not typically used for the initial diagnosis of TB?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) F/S Line Probe Assay

Explanation:

The F/S Line Probe Assay is not typically used for the initial diagnosis of TB according to NTEP guidelines.

Diagnostic Modality

Usage

Sputum Smear Microscopy

For initial screening and diagnosis, especially in resource-limited settings.

Chest X-ray

To support diagnosis when clinical suspicion is high.

TruNAAT/CBNAAT

For initial diagnosis, due to high sensitivity and specificity, rapid results.

Line Probe Assay (LPA)

For detecting drug resistance in confirmed TB cases.

Tuberculin Skin Test (TST)

For screening latent TB infection.

Interferon-Gamma Release Assays (IGRAs)

For detecting latent TB infection

Sputum Culture

Gold standard for TB diagnosis; takes several weeks to obtain results.

Drug Susceptibility Testing (DST)

To guide treatment by identifying drug-resistant strains in confirmed TB cases.

questions.text: Blood pressure of a 65-year-old male in the ICU crashes. ECG tracing shows Ventricular fibrillation. 200 J biphasic shock is given to patient. Which of the following is next best step for managment of this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Start CPR  

Immediately after defibrillation, the rhythm takes some time to reset to normal. During this time, chest compressions must continue @30:2.

questions.text: A 50 y/o man undergoes a total hip replacement. Postoperatively, he develops difficulty walking and reports numbness along the posterior thigh, lateral leg, and sole of the foot. O/E, he has weakness in extending the hip and flexing the knee. The injured nerve originates from which of the following spinal roots?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) L4–S3

 

Explanation:

The patient’s symptoms, including weakness in hip extension, knee flexion, and sensory loss along the posterior thigh and leg, are indicative of sciatic nerve injury.

  • The sciatic nerve originates from the ventral rami of the L4–S3 spinal roots.

    • L2–L4 (Option A) forms the femoral/obturator nerves.

    • L5–S1 (Option C) is part of the sacral plexus but not the full sciatic root

    • S1–S5 (Option D) contributes to the pudendal and coccygeal nerves.

Takeaway:

Sciatic nerve = largest nerve, root value L4–S3, vulnerable in hip surgery/injections.

 

 

Sciatic Nerve course

questions.text: A 45-year-old man who had been incarcerated for political dissent is reported to have died under suspicious circumstances. The autopsy reveals multiple injuries consistent with physical torture. In considering international guidelines for the medical investigation of such cases, which key document outlines principles and standards for identifying and investigating torture for a Police Surgeon?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Istanbul Protocol

Explanation:

Declaration / Document

Focus / Purpose

Istanbul Protocol

Documentation and investigation of torture and ill-treatment

Declaration of Tokyo

Guidelines for doctors on torture related to detention and imprisonment (Option A ruled out)

Declaration of Helsinki

Ethical principles for medical research involving human subjects (Option C ruled out)

Nuremberg Code

Ethics in human experimentation post-WWII (Option D ruled out)

Geneva Conventions

Treatment of combatants and civilians during armed conflict

Declaration of Malta

Guidelines on physicians’ roles during hunger strikes, especially in custodial settings

questions.text:
A 45-year-old female died within a few months after being diagnosed with renal cell carcinoma. The autopsy revealed a yellowish, spherical neoplasm in one pole of the kidney. The tumour cells invaded the renal vein and inferior vena cava. Histopathology is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

 


{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Clear cell RCC

 

Explanation:

  • The clinical scenario and the histopathology image is suggestive of Clear cell carcinoma

Clear cell carcinoma:

  • Classical clearing of cells is due to the accumulation of glycogen and lipids.
  • It is a yellowish neoplasm due to prominent lipid accumulation.
  • It is the most common renal cell carcinoma and is associated with the deletion of chromosome 3p which leads to Von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) syndrome

questions.text:
Which of the following is true regarding bile acid synthesis regulation?


	7α-hydroxylation is the step which is suppressed
	Cholic acid suppresses the synthesis
	Farnesoid X receptor is activated
	Transcription of the CYP7A1 gene is suppressed
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 1,3,4

Explanation:

  • Chenodeoxycholic acid (not cholic acid) is the most potent bile acid inhibitor.

  • It activates FXR, which suppresses CYP7A1 transcription, reducing 7α-hydroxylase activity (rate-limiting step).

  • This leads to ↓ bile acid synthesis.

questions.text: What effect does aldosterone have on acid secretion in the distal convoluted tubule (DCT) and collecting duct (CD)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Increases activity of H⁺-ATPase

Explanation:

  • In intercalated cells of the DCT and collecting duct, H⁺ is secreted via H⁺-ATPase and H⁺/K⁺ ATPase.
  • Aldosterone stimulates these proton pumps, enhancing urinary acidification and bicarbonate reabsorption.
  • This mechanism is independent of Na⁺ transport.

 

Takeaway:

  • Aldosterone = ↑ H⁺ secretion (via H⁺-ATPase) → helps maintain acid–base balance.
  • Decreases the activity of Hᐩ-ATPase (Option A): Aldosterone increases the activity of Hᐩ-ATPase but does not decrease it.
  • Inhibits the secretion of Hᐩ (Option B): Aldosterone enhances the secretion of Hᐩ, not inhibits it.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presented to the clinic with fever, joint pain, and rash with a history of sore throat about three weeks ago, which resolved without treatment. Examination reveals a rash characterized by pink to red lesions with well-defined borders and tender, swollen joints. What is the primary mechanism underlying the development of acute rheumatic fever (ARF) in this patient following the untreated sore throat?

choices.text: Direct invasion of tissues by streptococcal bacteria
Delayed hypersensitivity reaction to streptococcal exotoxins
Cross-reactivity between streptococcal antigens and host proteins
Activation of complement by streptococcal toxins

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Cross-reactivity between streptococcal antigens and host proteins

 

Explanation:

Acute rheumatic fever (ARF):

  • Symptoms / Clinical Features: Fever, Arthralgia / joint pain, Rash, Sore throat (3 weeks ago, indicative of prior streptococcal infection).

  • Causative agent of ARF is Group A beta-hemolytic Streptococcus (GABHS), also called Streptococcus pyogenes.

  • Underlying Mechanism: Molecular Mimicry / Cross-Reactivity:

    • ​​​​​​​Streptococcus M-protein is the major bacterial antigen.

    • Human glycoproteins are present in the heart, joints, and skin.

    • Similarity between M-protein and human glycoproteins (“twin brothers”) leads to mimicry.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old male presented with behavioral changes and involuntary movements over the past several weeks. Neurological examination revealed ataxia and myoclonus. He passed away after 4 months, and biopsy findings of the brain tissue are shown below. Based on these findings, which of the following statements is false regarding this condition?




	Proteinaceous particles with single-stranded RNA cause it.
	It results from the misfolding of PrPsc to PrPc.
	Spongiform transformation is a characteristic histopathological feature
	It is associated with a good prognosis if diagnosed early.
	Familial forms are associated with specific genetic mutations.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1, 2 and 4

Explanation:

  • The most likely diagnosis in this clinical presentation is Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD), a prion disease.

 

Prion Disease or Transmissible Spongiform Encephalopathy (TSE):

  • Prions are proteinaceous infectious particles with no RNA/DNA.
  • Pathogenesis: Misfolding of normal prion protein (PrPc) to form beta-pleated configuration (PrPSc).
  • Histopathology: Spongiform vacuolisation inside the cell.
  • Associated diseases:

Types of prion disease
1. Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (M/C)

  • Genetic: Familial form caused by PRNP mutation.
  • Transmission: Iatrogenic
  • Symptoms:
    • Dementia.
    • Associated pronounced involuntary jerking muscle contractions on sudden stimulation (startle myoclonus) and cerebellar dysfunction (ataxia).
  • Histopathogenesis:
    • Spongiform transformation of the cerebral cortex.
  • Prognosis: Uniformly fatal with average survival < 7 months after the onset of symptoms.

2. Kuru disease

  • PAS & Congo: red positive.
  • Kuru plaques: Extracellular aggregated abnormal PrP.

3. Fatal familial insomnia

4. Bovine spongiform encephalopathy

questions.text: What is the primary reason for applying ultrasound gel during an ultrasound examination?

choices.text: To act as a lubricant for easier probe movement
To eliminate air pockets between the probe and skin
To cool down the transducer while in constant use

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) To eliminate air pockets between the probe and skin

Explanation: 

Primary reason for applying ultrasound gel during an ultrasound examination to eliminate air pockets between the probe and skin. Although the gel can provide lubrication, its main purpose is not it. (Option B ruled out)

 

Ultrasound Gel

Purpose of Gel
  • Eliminates air pockets between probe and skin for effective sound transmission. (Option C)
  • Serves as a medium for sound and lubricant.

Preferred Gel
  • Hydrogel is preferred over Lipogel for easier cleaning.

Ingredients
  • Distilled water, carbomer, ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA), propylene glycol, glycerin, trolamine, and occasionally contains blue colorant.

Infection Control

Cover transducer and skin with plastic for patients with open wounds or skin issues.

↓

Apply gel on both sides of the plastic.

↓

Clean transducer after each use

questions.text: A 24-year-old male presents with recurrent painful swelling and discharge at the natal cleft. He has coarse hair and reports worsening after prolonged sitting. On examination, a tender fluctuant swelling with a midline pit is noted.What is the most appropriate initial management?

choices.text: Complete surgical excision of the sinus

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Drainage through a midline incision

Explanation:

Drainage through a midline incision is the most appropriate initial management for an acute pilonidal abscess.

  • It involves creating a small incision to drain the abscess and clean the cavity.
  • Pilonidal sinuses are found in the natal cleft (the groove at the top of the buttocks), consisting of one or more skin openings connected to a subcutaneous track lined with granulation tissue, often containing hair.

 

Treatment Options:

  • Conservative:
    • Cleaning, hair removal, and hygiene maintenance.
    • Cauterization with silver nitrate or laser
  • Acute Abscess Treatment:
    • Drainage through a small longitudinal incision over the abscess (Option C ruled out).
  • Surgical: 
    • Laying open sinus tracks (with/without marsupialisation)
    • Complete excision (with/without primary closure)
    • Off-midline closure techniques (Limberg, Z-plasty, Karydakis procedures).
    • Bascom Procedure: Lateral incision to clean the sinus cavity, excise midline pits, and leave lateral wounds open to heal secondarily.
    • Flap Procedures: If initial treatments fail or if the sinus recurs

 Pilonidal sinus excision and repair by rhomboid flap

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with diplopia that develops daily in evening hours along with difficulty in swallowing. On examination left eye ptosis is noted. Ice pack test shows improvement in ptosis. Repetitive nerve stimulation shows a decremental response. The report of antibody panel is awaited. Which of the following will not be useful in management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct answer-A) Physostigmine

  • This is a case of Myasthenia Gravis, as diurnal variation of neuro-symptoms is seen, and the ice pack test shows resolution of ptosis. 
  • Physostigmine crosses the blood-brain barrier and has central action. It has no role in the management of disorders of the peripheral nervous system.

Plasma exchange (Option B) & Intravenous immunoglobulins (Option D): IVIg and PLEX would be required if this patient develops Myasthenic crisis.  

Pyridostigmine (Option C): Pyridostigmine is an anticholinesterase drug that is specifically used to increase acetylcholine activity at the neuromuscular junction, making it the most appropriate treatment for this patient

questions.text: Which of the following diseases can be treated with a drug that inhibits vesicular monoamine transporters (VMAT)?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Huntington’s chorea

EXPLANATION:

Movement disorders like Huntington’s chorea and tardive dyskinesia can be treated with drugs that inhibit vesicular monoamine transporters (VMAT).

  • As the name suggests, VMATs are transporters of monoamines, especially catecholamines (adrenaline, noradrenaline, and dopamine), within storage vesicles.
  • They are mainly of three types - VMAT 1, VMAT 2 & VAchT.

Centrally, this process mainly involves the release of dopamine, which is abnormal in movement disorders involving excessive dopaminergic activity.

Peripherally, this process occurs at the synaptic terminals, which are responsible for maintaining blood pressure; hence, these drugs were once used to manage hypertension.

Inhibitors: Tetrabenazine, deutetrabenazine, valbenazine

Inhibitor: Reserpine

These drugs selectively inhibit VMAT-1

This drug inhibits both VMAT-1 & VMAT-2

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, who gave birth 3 months ago, presents with symptoms of anxiety, palpitations, and weight loss. Her thyroid function tests reveal abnormalities. What is the most likely phase of postpartum thyroiditis she is experiencing?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Thyrotoxic phase

Explanation:

Postpartum thyroiditis:

Definition

Postpartum thyroiditis is an inflammation of the thyroid gland that occurs after childbirth, typically within the first year postpartum

Etiology
  • Autoimmune Factors
  • Genetic Predisposition
  • Hormonal Changes

Clinical manifestations

It has 2 phases which has a clinical progression-

Thyrotoxic phase( 1-4 months) (Option A)

Hypothyroid phase( 4 to 8 months) (Option B)

The hypothyroid phase either leads to euthyroid phase (Option C) or permanent hypothyroidism (Option D).

Investigation

Thyroid Function Tests:

  • TSH: Elevated in the hypothyroid phase, suppressed in the hyperthyroid phase.
  • Free T4: Elevated in the hyperthyroid phase, decreased in the hypothyroid phase.
  • Free T3: May also be elevated in the hyperthyroid phase.

Thyroid Antibodies:

  • Anti-thyroid Peroxidase (Anti-TPO) Antibodies: Often elevated, indicating an autoimmune component.

Treatment:
  1. Hyperthyroid phase- Beta blockers
  2. Hypothyroid phase- Levothyroxine, (25 mcg to 75 mcg)

questions.text: How does the Multidimensional Poverty Index (MPI) offer a more comprehensive view of poverty than traditional income-based measures?

choices.text: By measuring only the income levels of households.
By focusing solely on the employment status of individuals.
By including various indicators of health, education, and living standards.
By evaluating the GDP per capita of the country.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) By including various indicators of health, education, and living standards.

Explanation:

  • Multidimensional poverty index (MDPI) complements traditional monetary poverty measures by simultaneously capturing the acute deprivations in:
    • Health
    • Education 
    • Living standards of the person
  • MDPI is interpreted in the range of 0-1.
  • The use of MDPI is the measure of acute poverty.
  • India’s MDPI is 0.121, with a 27.5% poor population.
  • The Human Poverty Index (HPI) was replaced by the MDPI in 2010, as it was not specific to any group of people.
  • Individuals are classified as multidimensionally deprived if they fall short in at least one dimension or in a combination of indicators that total the weight of a full dimension.
  • Households are considered poor if deprived in indicators adding up to 1/3 or more.

Dimensions of Poverty

Indicator

Health

Nutrition (1/6)

Child mortality (1/6)

Education

Years of schooling (1/6)

School attendance (1/6)

Standard of living

Cooking Fuel (1/18)

Sanitation (1/18)

Drinking Water (1/18)

Electricity (1/18)

Housing (1/18)

Assets (1/18)

questions.text: Which of the following would decrease the conduction velocity of an action potential along an axon?

choices.text: Increasing the diameter of the axon.
Decreasing the capacitance of the membrane.
Increasing the myelination of the axon.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Increasing the axoplasmic resistance.

Explanation:

  • Increasing this resistance would hinder the spread of Na+ ions, making it more difficult to reach the threshold for action potential initiation at adjacent nodes of Ranvier.
  • Conduction velocity depends on axon diameter, myelination, internal resistance, and membrane capacitance.

    • ↑ Axoplasmic resistance → slows Na⁺ spread → ↓ conduction velocity 

    • ↑ Diameter & myelination → increase velocity

    • ↓ Capacitance → faster depolarization

questions.text:
A 72-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of severe abdominal pain and distension. An upright chest X-ray is performed, showing the following finding:



Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis based on this radiographic finding?
questions.solution:
Answer: B) Pneumoperitoneum

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation and radiological image indicate pneumoperitoneum, which can be identified by the classical Rigler sign (yellow arrows) seen in the given X-ray, also known as the double-wall sign, which is seen when gas outlines both sides of the bowel wall, i.e., gas within the bowel's lumen and gas within the peritoneal cavity. Red arrows in the X-ray show gas under the diaphragm. 
  • Pneumoperitoneum refers to the presence of free air in the peritoneal cavity, often indicating a perforated hollow viscus.

Pneumoperitoneum- Radiological findings

Imaging Modality

Key Findings of Pneumoperitoneum

Upright Chest X-ray
  • Subdiaphragmatic free gas
  • Continuous diaphragm sign

Supine Abdominal X-ray
  • Rigler's sign (gas within the bowel's lumen and gas within the peritoneal cavity)
  • Cupola sign (air beneath the dome of the diaphragm)
  • Football sign (oval-shaped collection of air in the upper abdomen)
  • Triangular air collection in Morrison's pouch

 

Rigler sign

Cupola sign

questions.text: A 10 year old girl has always loved school but is now struggling academically. Her teacher notes that she confuses similar-looking letters when reading and has trouble decoding words. She often asks for help with reading and feels frustrated with writing tasks. Her writing is messy and often lacks punctuation. Although she can do basic math, she struggles to remember mathematical signs and makes careless calculation errors. Which specific learning disorder is she most likely experiencing?

choices.text: Specific learning disorder with impairment in reading
Specific learning disorder with impairment in written expression
Specific learning disorder with impairment in mathematics

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Mixed disorder of scholastic skills

 

Explanation:

The child exhibits impairments in reading (difficulty decoding words), written expression (messy writing, omitted punctuation), and mathematics (difficulty with signs and calculations). The combination of these challenges indicates a mixed disorder of scholastic skills.

 

Specific Learning Disorders

 

  • Neurodevelopmental disorder beginning in early childhood
  • Both heritable and environmental factors like lead poisoning, Fetal Alcohol Syndrome, and in-utero drug exposure are responsible.
  • Persistent difficulty in learning academic skills such as reading, written expression or mathematics.
  • Inconsistent with the intellectual ability of the child.
  • The IQ range is usually normal.

 

Types of Specific Learning Disorders

Specific learning disorder with impairment in reading (Dyslexia)

Specific learning disorder with impairment in written expression (Specific Spelling Disorder/ Dysgraphia)

Specific learning disorder with impairment in mathematics (dyscalculia)

Mixed disorder of scholastic skills

 

Specific learning disorder with impairment in reading (Option A), Specific learning disorder with impairment in written expression (Option B), and Specific learning disorder with impairment in mathematics (Option C) each focus on individual disabilities associated with reading, writing, and math, respectively, while this child exhibits difficulties across all three areas.

questions.text: According to the two-cell two-gonadotropin theory, which hormone stimulates the conversion of androgens to estrogens in granulosa cells?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) FSH

Explanation:

According to the Two-cell Two-Gonadotropin Theory:

  • The ovary has two cellular components: Theca cells and Granulosa cells.
  • Theca cells → express receptors for LH.
  • Granulosa cells → express receptors for FSH.
  • LH stimulation of theca cells → production of androgens (testosterone, androstenedione).
  • FSH stimulation of granulosa cells→ conversion of these androgens to estrogens (estradiol, estrone) through the aromatase enzyme.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents with a painless midline neck swelling that has been present since childhood and has gradually increased in size. The swelling moves upward on protrusion of the tongue. Ultrasound shows a cystic midline lesion .Which of the following is the correct statement regarding this condition?

choices.text: High risk of developing squamous cell carcinoma
Removal of the cyst along with the tract and part of the hyoid bone is done
Most commonly seen in the suprahyoid region
Incision and Drainage are the preferred management

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Removal of the cyst along with the tract and part of the hyoid bone is done

Explanation:

The clinical presentation and image classically suggest a Thyroglossal cyst, which is managed by removing the cyst along with the tract up to the base of the tongue and part of the hyoid bone (SISTRUNK Procedure) to minimize the recurrence.

  • A congenital neck mass resulting from the persistence of the thyroglossal duct, an embryological structure (can also be present in adulthood).
  • The cyst represents a remnant of this duct and can be found anywhere along the midline from the base of the tongue to the thyroid isthmus.
  • It presents as midline swelling that moves with deglutition and protrusion of the tongue.
  • Most Common Site: Subhyoid (Option C ruled out)
  • Treatment:
    • Sistrunk Procedure: Complete surgical excision of the cyst and its tract up to the base of the tongue, as well as a portion of the hyoid bone, to prevent recurrence.
    • Incision and drainage are never done (Option D ruled out) as they lead to the formation of a Thyroglossal fistula. (also forms if an inflamed cyst ruptures) - Always Acquired.
  • Long-standing thyroglossal cyst -  > Risk of developing into Papillary thyroid carcinoma. (Option A ruled out)

questions.text: You are educating a mother of  8-year-old girl with type 1 Diabetes Mellitus about insulin administration techniques. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding insulin delivery?

choices.text: The preferred site for subcutaneous insulin injection is the anterior abdominal wall.
Insulin pens should be held at a 90° angle to the skin for optimal delivery
Repeated insulin injections at the same site can cause lipohypertrophy
Repeat the insulin injection spot after 5-7 days

questions.solution:
Correct answer is D: Repeat the insulin injection site after 5-7 days

  • Repeating the same injection spot should be avoided for at least 2 weeks to allow tissue healing and reduce lipodystrophy risk. 
  • Repeated use of the same site may cause lipodystrophy. Lipohypertrophy is more common and is seen due to the anabolic effects of insulin. 
  • The anterior abdominal wall is the preferred site due to consistent absorption.
  • 90° angle ensures proper SC delivery using insulin pens or syringes.

questions.text: A 30-year-old presents with right-sided hearing loss, vertigo, and horizontal nystagmus with fast phase to the right. The nystagmus worsens in darkness and improves with fixation. There is no nausea or vomiting. What is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Central vestibular nystagmus due to a cerebellar lesion
Peripheral vestibular nystagmus due to serous labyrinthitis
Peripheral vestibular nystagmus due to purulent labyrinthitis
Central vestibular nystagmus due to Arnold-Chiari malformation

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Peripheral vestibular nystagmus due to serous labyrinthitis

 

Explanation:

The patient’s horizontal nystagmus, with a fast phase to the right, worsens in darkness and improves with fixation, which suggests peripheral vestibular nystagmus due to serous labyrinthitis.

Feature

Peripheral Nystagmus

Central Nystagmus

Location of lesion

Labyrinth or vestibulocochlear (VIII) nerve

Central neural pathways (vestibular nuclei, brainstem, cerebellum)

Latency

2-20 seconds

No latency

Duration

Less than 1 minute

More than 1 minute

Type of Nystagmus

Spontaneous nystagmus

Gaze-Evoked Nystagmus

Direction of Nystagmus

Fixed, towards the undermost ear

Change with direction of gaze

Fatigability

Fatigable

Non-fatigable

Response to Visual Fixation

Suppressed by Optic fixation; Worsens in darkness or with Frenzel glasses (+20 dioptre glasses), both abolishing optic fixation

Cannot be suppressed

Accompanying Symptoms
  • Severe vertigo
  • Loss of hearing in one ear
  • Ringing in one or both ears
  • Difficulty focusing vision
  • Loss of balance

None or slight:

  • Impairment in speech
  • Weakness or numbness
  • Gait disturbance
  • Impairment in vision

 

In Purulent Labyrinthitis (Option C), Vertigo is due to the inner ear bacterial infection, with total loss of cochlear and vestibular functions. Nystagmus would be on the opposite side, and there would be severe nausea and vomiting.

 

Central Vestibular Nystagmus (Option A and D) does not improve with optic fixation and has changing directions.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a history of chronic alcohol use presents to the emergency with sudden onset loss of consciousness and seizures. He also shows signs of confusion, apathy, dementia, visual hallucinations and aggressive behavior. An MRI is performed, revealing the findings shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Marchiafava-Bignami Syndrome

 

Explanation:
The sudden onset of neurological symptoms along with the characteristic MRI findings of high signal intensity in the splenium of the corpus callosum, coupled with the patient's chronic alcohol use, strongly indicates Marchiafava-Bignami Syndrome.

Fig: An axial T2-weighted MR image reveals signal abnormalities in the corpus callosum and periventricular white matter.

Fig: A sagittal T1-weighted MR image demonstrates corpus callosum atrophy (short arrow). The central layers of the corpus callosum appear hypointense, while the dorsal and ventral layers are spared, creating the characteristic "sandwich sign" (long arrow)

Fig: Axial T1 weighted image after fat saturation and gadolinium injection. Peripheral rim enhancement (arrow) of splenium.Diffuse mild cortical and subcortical atrophy is also present.


Marchiafava Bignami Syndrome

 

Marchiafava-Bignami Disease:
A rare alcohol-related neurological disorder causing demyelination and necrosis of the corpus callosum, due to vitamin B1 deficiency and oxidative stress.

  • Acute: Sudden LOC, seizures, confusion, psychosis.

  • Subacute: Depression, ataxia, apraxia, dysarthria, dyslexia.

  • Chronic: Progressive dementia, hallucinations, delusions, behavioral changes.

MRI (Gold standard):

  • "Sandwich sign" in splenium (T2 hyperintensity, T1 hypointensity, rim enhancement), ± subcortical atrophy.

Treatment:
IV thiamine, vitamin B complex, folate, amantadine, and strict alcohol cessation.

 

Alcohol Induced Dementia (Option A):Recent memory loss, cognitive decline (incl. language), with ventricular enlargement and cerebral atrophy seen in ~50–70%. Changes may reverse after 1 year of abstinence. 

 

Wernicke's Encephalopathy (Option B): Although confusion is present, the classical triad includes ophthalmoplegia, ataxia, and confusion. MRI findings would typically show hyperintensities in the periaqueductal gray matter, mammillary bodies, hypothalamus, and medial thalami, which were not observed in this case.

 

Alexander Disease (Option D) is a leukodystrophy that affects the brain's white matter, it typically presents in childhood or early adulthood and is characterized by other clinical features such as developmental delays and seizures, which do not align with this patient's presentation.

questions.text: What is the primary objective of the Kishori Shakti Yojana?

choices.text: Promoting higher education among adolescent girls
Ensuring maternal healthcare for pregnant women
Empowering adolescent girls through nutrition and health education
Providing financial assistance for marriage expenses

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Empowering adolescent girls through nutrition and health education

Explanation:

Kishori Shakti Yojana aims to empower adolescent girls through nutrition and health education.

  • Part of the existing ICDS scheme
  • Targets adolescent girls 11-18 years
  • Provides education on health, hygiene, and nutrition
  • Encourages girls to be in school

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents to the emergency department following minor trauma from bumping into a table corner. Physical examination reveals a bluish discoloration on the thigh. Based on its appearance, what is the most likely age of the bruise?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Few hours to 3 days

Explanation:

The above clinical scenario shows a blue-colored bruise that can be considered to be around a few hours to 3 days old.

 

Color Change Rate (due to hemoglobin breakdown)

Color of bruise

Age of bruise

Red (oxygenated blood)

Fresh bruise/ 1-2 hours

Blue (deoxyhemoglobin)

A few hours to 3 days (Option C)

Bluish-black to brown (hemosiderin)

4th day (Option A ruled out)

Greenish (haematoidin/biliverdin)

5 to 6 days (Option B ruled out)

Yellow (bilirubin)

7 to 12 days

Normal

2 weeks (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with an erythematous, swollen patch in a skin lesion on the face, along with significant oedema of the hands and feet. She reports the patch has been present for several months now, but has only recently turned painful and red. Additionally, the patient experiences pain and tenderness along multiple nerves and reports a general feeling of fatigue and malaise. The patient has been on regular medications but is unsure about their names. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Type 1 lepra reaction

 

Explanation:

  • History of a pre-existing skin lesion on the face turning red and swollen, along with significant oedema of the hands and feet, is indicative of Type 1 lepra reaction
  • Pain and tenderness over multiple nerves are other characteristic features of Type 1 lepra reaction.
  • Type 1 lepra reaction is a type IV hypersensitivity reaction, that typically occurs in patients with borderline leprosy (BT, BB, or BL disease).
  • It is characterized by an inflammatory response to Mycobacterium leprae antigens usually seen on starting MDT, resulting in a sudden exacerbation of pre-existing skin lesions and nerve involvement.


Cellulitis (Option A):Acute, painful, red swelling of skin and subcutis, usually post-injury; differs from lepra reaction in presentation.


Psoriasis (Option C):

  • It is a chronic autoimmune skin condition characterized by red, scaly patches on the skin, over the elbows, knees, scalp, and lower back. 


Erythema multiforme (Option D): Hypersensitivity reaction with target lesions, often post-infection or drug-related; not consistent with leprosy reaction.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with a slowly enlarging, painless lesion on the neck. She has a history of pulmonary tuberculosis with nodal involvement, treated 3 years ago. On examination, there is a firm, erythematous plaque with crusting and shallow ulceration. Ipsilateral, non-tender cervical lymphadenopathy is also noted. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Scrofuloderma

Explanation:

The given clinical scenario and the image suggest a diagnosis of Scrofuloderma, which is caused by the direct extension of an infection (endogenous spread) to the skin from the underlying TB focus (Lymph node, bone joint).

  • It is a multibacillary manifestation and is the most common form of cutaneous TB in children, although it can occur in any age group.
  • It often presents as painless subcutaneous swellings and ruptures into the overlying skin, resulting in discharging sinuses or undermined ulcers or fibrotic scars.
  • The most common focus of infection is the cervical lymph node.
  • The most common sites are the neck and axilla.
  • Biopsy reveals positive staining for acid-fast bacilli and characteristic caseating granulomas seen.

Actinomycosis (Option B): Chronic bacterial infection causing indurated nodules or abscesses with sinus tracts and sulfur granules.
Unlike scrofuloderma, it lacks caseating nodules.

Sporotrichosis (Option C): Fungal infection  presenting as painless papules/nodules after trauma, spreading linearly along lymphatics.
Unlike scrofuloderma, it lacks central caseation.

Pyoderma gangrenosum (Option D) : Rare, non-infectious ulcers with undermined borders, linked to systemic diseases (IBD, RA, hematologic malignancies).
Histology shows neutrophilic infiltrate without infection, vasculitis, or granulomas

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient reports difficulty hearing in the Right ear. Pure tone audiometry is done and the result is given in the image below. Given the audiometric findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Conductive Hearing Loss

 

Explanation:

  • Given that the audiometric findings show a significant A-B gap with normal BC thresholds and poorer AC thresholds, the most likely diagnosis is Conductive Hearing Loss, typically due to issues in the outer or middle ear.

 

 


 

Normal Ear:

 Conductive Hearing Loss (Option A): 

  • AC Thresholds: Elevated (poorer hearing) compared to normal.
  • BC Thresholds: Within normal limits.
  • A-B Gap (>20db): Significant

 

Sensorineural Hearing Loss (SNHL) (Option B) :

  • AC Thresholds: Elevated
  • BC Thresholds: Elevated to the same degree as AC.
  • A-B Gap: Minimal or absent

 

Presbycusis (Option C) :

  • AC Thresholds: Elevated, particularly in high frequencies.
  • BC Thresholds: Elevated with greater loss in higher frequencies.
  • A-B Gap: Minimal
  • Downsloping

Meniere’s Disease (Option D): 

  • Upsloping
  • A-B Gap: Typically minimal

questions.text: A 45 year old gardener presents to the clinic with a persistent itchy rash on his exposed skin areas, including the face, neck, and arms.
