On examination, there are erythematous, scaly plaques with some vesicles and lichenification shown below. He mentions that he often works near a patch of wild plants that have small white flowers. Which of the following is the causative agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Parthenium hysterophorus

Explanation:

  • The given clinical scenario shows leonine facies due to chronic airborne contact dermatitis. Given his occupation as a farmer, this is likely phytophotodermatitis (PPD) caused by Parthenium hysterophorus.

 

Parthenium hysterophorus:

Parthenium dermatitis: Caused by airborne sesquiterpene lactone from Parthenium (congress grass).
Affects exposed areas (face, neck, hands) in farmers/outdoor workers.
Presents as subacute eczema; chronic cases may develop leonine facies.

 

Leonine faces:                                                  

     

 

Lesions on the back of hand:         

      

   

  • Other causes of Phytodermatitis (dermatitis due to plants) are:-
  • Xanthium Strumarium
  • Chrysanthemums
  • Sunflowers
  • Dahlia.

 

Treatment includes covering the body from exposure and taking a bath when returning home. Pharmacotherapy includes antihistamines, corticosteroids, and azathioprine.

PTBP (Option B)Para-tert-butylphenol is found in the adhesive of bindi which acts as an allergen and causes allergic contact dermatitis.

Poison ivy (Option C) can cause acute ACD. However, this would present with erythematous, intensely itchy lesions in the area of contact with the plant leaf/ branch.

PPD (Option ) Para-phenylenediamine is an allergen found in hair dyes causing allergic contact dermatitis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presented with complaints of a persistent dry cough for the past week and an antitussive was prescribed. Two days later, the patient returned with nausea, vomiting, and constipation. Which centrally acting antitussive medication is most likely responsible for these adverse effects in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Codeine

Explanation:

The patient presents with symptoms suggestive of codeine-induced adverse effects, including nausea, vomiting, and constipation. Opioids commonly cause gastrointestinal adverse effects due to agonistic activity on their receptors in the gastrointestinal tract.

Centrally acting Antitussives:

Class

Drugs

Mechanism

Adverse effects

Opioids
  • Morphine
    • Hydromorphone
    • Oxymorphone
  • Codeine
    • Hydrocodone
    • Oxycodone
    • Pholcodine

Suppress cough centre

Codeine -

  • Constipation
  • Respiratory depression
  • Drowsiness

Non Opioids
  • Dextromethorphan
  • Noscapine
  • Dextromethorphan- Acts on glutamate receptor-NMDA antagonist.
  • Noscapine-Sigma agonist

Dextromethorphan-

  • Dizziness
  • Nausea
  • Drowsiness
  • At high doses-
    • Hallucinations
    • Ataxia

Antihistaminic drugs
  • Cetirizine
  • Promethazine

H1 receptor antagonists
  • Drowsiness
  • Sedation
  • Somnolence
  • Fatigue
  • Headache

Dextromethorphan (Option B), noscapine (Option C) and promethazine (Option D) are less likely to cause gastrointestinal adverse effects compared to codeine.

questions.text: Which of the following statements best describes the nature of vegetation in infective endocarditis (IE)?

choices.text: Typically contain only fibrin and inflammatory cells
Most commonly found on the tricuspid valve

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Prone to embolisation

Explanation:

  • Vegetation in infective endocarditis is large and bulky, typically composed of fibrin, platelets, microorganisms, and inflammatory cells (Option B)

  • Embolization: Due to bulkiness, parts of the vegetation can break off, and these detached fragments are called emboli, which can travel through the bloodstream, causing systemic embolization. 

  • Embolization is common but not guaranteed.

Smooth and non-destructive lesions (Option A): Seen in non-bacterial thrombotic endocarditis (NBTE), not in infective endocarditis.

Contain only fibrin and inflammatory cells (Option B): IE vegetations also include microorganisms and platelets.

Most commonly found on the tricuspid valve (Option D): True mainly in IV drug users; overall, the mitral valve is the most commonly affected.

questions.text: A CKD patient is determined to have adynamic bone disease. Which of the following is the best explanation for this presentation?

choices.text: Excessive use of vitamin D preparations and phosphate binders
Less use of vitamin D preparations and phosphate binders

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Excessive use of vitamin D preparations and phosphate binders:

  • Adynamic Bone Disease in CKD Characterized by low bone turnover (↓ osteoblast & osteoclast activity) and is often iatrogenic.
  • It results from over-suppression of PTH due to use of calcitriol and calcium-containing phosphate binders like calcium acetate and calcium carbonate.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male complains of deep-seated headaches and visual disturbances. Imaging reveals a sphenoid sinus mucocele compressing adjacent structures. Which of the following is most likely to be compressed by this mucocele?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Optic nerve


Explanation:

The optic nerve runs along the superior wall of the sphenoid sinus and is the most likely structure compressed by a mucocele, leading to visual symptoms.

Anatomical Relations of the Sphenoid Sinus

  • Lateral wall: Related to the optic nerve, internal carotid artery, and maxillary nerve.

  • Posterior wall: Adjacent to the sella turcica (above) and clivus (below).

  • Roof: Related to the optic chiasma, olfactory tract, frontal lobe, and pituitary gland.

  • Floor: Related to the Vidian nerve and sphenopalatine nerve branches.

 

Mandibular nerve (Option B) runs through the infratemporal fossa, not in direct contact with the sphenoid sinus.

 

Middle meningeal artery (Option C) courses through the temporal bone, not near the sphenoid sinus.

 

Superior sagittal sinus (Option D) is located along the midline of the brain, distant from the sphenoid sinus.

questions.text:
An elderly male patient presents with superficial vesicles and bullae seen in the face, scalp, and upper trunk. Most of the bullae have ruptured resulting in well-demarcated crusted erosions surrounded by erythema. Histopathological examination reveal following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Pemphigus foliaceus

Explanation:

The clinical features and imaging showing intraepidermal cleavage with acantholysis beneath the stratum corneum (subcorneal splitting) point to a diagnosis of Pemphigus Foliaceus.

Pemphigus foliaceus is a group of immunobullous disorders caused by antibodies against desmosomal proteins mainly Desmosome-1.

  • Desmosomes maintain the structure of the epidermis through their adhesive function.
  • It presents as superficial vesicles or bullae that rupture easily, causing eroded skin lesions with surrounding erythema and crusting.

Pemphigus Vulgaris (Option A) presents as flaccid blisters and erosions involving both the skin and mucous membrane. The target antigens for PV is most commonly Desmoglein 3, sometimes desmoglein 1

 

Staphylococcal Scalded Skin Syndrome (SSSS) (Option C) Caused by Staph. aureus toxins (A/B), seen in neonates with flaccid bullae and crusting on face, axillae, groin.
No mucosal involvement (unlike PV); targets desmoglein 1.

 


Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS) (Option D) and toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN) are severe drug reactions causing mucocutaneous blistering, starting on face and flexures, followed by skin sloughing.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents with persistent nasal congestion, facial pain exacerbated by bending forward, thick yellow nasal discharge, and reduced olfaction for two weeks. CT imaging reveals abnormalities in the paranasal sinuses. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Sinusitis

Explanation: 

The patient’s symptoms of nasal congestion, facial pain localized to the cheeks, thick yellowish nasal discharge, and the findings on CT imaging showing sinus mucosal thickening and frothy fluid appearnace indicate maxillary sinusitis.

Sinusitis: Inflammation of the mucosal lining of the paranasal sinuses, often associated with infection/allergy.
Acute Sinusitis
  • Symptoms lasting less than 4 weeks
  • CT: Frothy appearance due to presence of bubbles in fluid

  • Treatment
    • Most cases resolve spontaneously; symptomatic relief with nasal decongestants, saline nasal sprays, and analgesics.
    • Antibiotics if bacterial infection is suspected (typically after 7-10 days of symptoms).
Subacute sinusitis

Symptoms lasting 4 to 12 weeks.
Chronic sinusitis
  • Symptoms lasting longer than 12 weeks.
  • CT: Bony sclerosis is seen and no air.

  • Treatment
    • Intranasal corticosteroids to reduce inflammation.
    • Saline irrigation.
    • Antibiotics for bacterial exacerbations.
    • Surgery (e.g., functional endoscopic sinus surgery) in refractory cases to improve drainage.

 

Viral rhinitis (Option A) presents with clear nasal discharge and lacks significant mucosal thickening or air-fluid levels on imaging.

Allergic rhinitis (Option B) is characterized by clear rhinorrhea, nasal itching, and sneezing, without purulent discharge or air-fluid levels.

Nasal polyps (Option D) may cause nasal obstruction but are not typically associated with acute purulent discharge or air-fluid levels on imaging.

questions.text: A physiologist is studying blood flow in a network of four parallel blood vessels. The effective resistance of the network of vessels is 4.8 R units. The pressure at the proximal end of the network is 150 mmHg, and the pressure at the distal end is 90 mmHg. What is the total blood flow rate through the network of vessels?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Effective Perfusion Pressure = 150 mmHg − 90 mmHg= 60 mmHg
  • Using the blood flow analogue of Ohm's law: Blood flow (F) in any part of the circulatory system is determined by the effective perfusion pressure (P) and the resistance (R) it encounters: F = P/R
    • 𝑅 total = 4.8R units
    • Flow = Pressure / Resistance = 60/4.8 =12.5 L/s

questions.text: A 32-year-old female patient has been complaining of persistent sadness, fatigue, and difficulty concentrating over the past few months. Upon examination, you notice several physical signs on her face, which are shown below (asterisk). Identify the sign shown in the image.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Omega Sign

 

Explanation: The omega sign, an omega-shaped fold on the forehead from excessive use of the corrugator muscle, reflects emotional stress and is indicative of depressive disorders.

Physical Signs of Depression:

Veraguth's Fold (Option A)

Omega Sign (Option B)

A triangular fold in the inner corner of the upper eyelid due to changes in the corrugator and zygomatic muscles from prolonged muscle tension associated with depression.

 


 

An omega-shaped fold on the forehead reflecting excessive use of the corrugator muscle, indicative of emotional stress related to depressive disorders.


 

Chandler’s Sign (Option C): Not relevant to psychiatry; refers to eyelid swelling, proptosis, and restricted eye movement, seen in orbital infections like cellulitis.

 

Dennie-Morgan Lines (Option D): These are associated with allergic conditions, particularly atopic dermatitis, and are characterized by extra folds of skin beneath the eyes. They are not indicative of depressive disorders.

questions.text: Patient on ceftriaxone develops watery loose stools and low-grade fever. Blood counts show TLC of 15000 cells/cu.mm. Which of the following test will help in quick detection of an incriminating organism?

choices.text: NAAT for toxin A and Toxin B in stool
EIA for toxin A and toxin B in stool

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) NAAT for toxin A and Toxin B in stool

Explantion:

  • NAAT / PCR is part of the diagnostic criteria of PMC and gives high diagnostic sensitivity and specificity.
  • Other tests include
    • ELISA 
    • Colonoscopy (ulcers, plaques, pseudomembrane can be visualized)
    • CECT- Accordion sign

Option B: EIA has high sensitivity but lacks specificity.

Option C: is specific but not sensitive as pseudo membranes take time to develop.

Option D: can be used, but Harrison says turnaround time is too slow for practical use.

questions.text: Which of the following would possibly confirm the diagnosis of myasthenia gravis following an Edrophonium test?

choices.text: No change in muscle strength after administration of edrophonium
Worsening of muscle weakness after administration of edrophonium
Temporary improvement in muscle strength after administration of edrophonium
Development of severe muscle cramps after administration of edrophonium

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Temporary improvement in muscle strength after administration of edrophonium

Explanation:

The edrophonium (Tensilon) test helps differentiate between myasthenic (arising from inadequate acetylcholine at the NMJ) and cholinergic crises (resulting from excessive acetylcholine stimulation due to anticholinesterase medication overdose), which present with similar symptoms but require opposite treatments.

 

Tensilon test

  • The tensilon test involves the injection of 10 mg i.v. Edrophonium, a short-acting anticholinesterase agent.
  • Steps: 2 mg i.v. Edrophonium → Observe for any adverse reactions → If no adverse reactions occur after 30–60 seconds, the remaining 8 mg is injected.

Results:

  • Myasthenia Gravis: Short-lasting improvement in muscle strength.
  • Other Muscular Dystrophies: No improvement. (Option A)
  • Cholinergic crisis: No improvement or a worsening of their condition. (Option B)

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the dose-response curves for benzodiazepines (Blue curve) and barbiturates (Red curve) is correct?

choices.text: Benzodiazepines demonstrate a steeper dose-response curve compared to barbiturates.
Benzodiazepines have a wider therapeutic index compared to barbiturates.
Both benzodiazepines and barbiturates display a linear dose-response relationship.
Benzodiazepines and barbiturates show similar potency but differ in their maximal efficacy on the dose-response curve.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Benzodiazepines have a wider therapeutic index compared to barbiturates.

Explanation:

A linear dose-response relationship implies that the response increases proportionally with increasing dosage.

  • Benzodiazepines have a wider therapeutic index, making them safer for clinical use.

  • Barbiturates possess a narrow therapeutic index, meaning the difference between therapeutic and toxic doses is small, increasing the risk of overdose.

    • It exhibit a steeper dose-response curve, leading to a rapid progression from sedation to anesthesia and potentially fatal respiratory depression.

questions.text: A 12-year-old child’s growth chart shows a distinctive pattern in the graph depicting their growth over time as shown in the image below. In this clinical scenario, what does the graph primarily indicate about the child’s growth patterns?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Somatic growth

 

Explanation:

In this clinical scenario, the sigmoid (S-shaped) curve primarily indicates the pattern of somatic growth, which refers to the child's height growth during childhood and adolescence.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with recurrent syncopal episodes. Auscultation reveals an ejection systolic murmur heard at the right 2nd intercostal space and radiates to the carotids. The murmur also becomes higher-pitched when heard at the apex. ECG shows left axis deviation with a normal sinus rhythm.  Which condition is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Aortic Stenosis

Explantion:

The given clinical presentation of Syncopal episodes with an Ejection systolic murmur in the geriatric age group points to valvular aortic stenosis. 

  • The ejection systolic murmur of aortic stenosis has two components:

    1. Low-frequency, harsh component – heard at right upper sternal border (RUSB)

    2. High-frequency musical component – transmitted to the apex = Gallavardin phenomenon/effect

 

Gallavardin Effect:

  • It refers to the phenomenon where a murmur of aortic stenosis (AS) becomes higher-pitched and more acoustically pure when auscultated at the apex of the heart despite originating from the aortic region.
  • The ejection (mid) systolic (Crescendo-decrescendo) murmur of AS typically starts shortly after S1, increases in intensity, peaks during ejection, and ends just before aortic valve closure.

questions.text:
Match the following deficiencies with their respective impacts:


 


	
		
			
			1) Adenosylcobalamin Deficiency
			
			
			a) Elevated homocysteine levels
			
		
		
			
			2) Methylcobalamin Deficiency
			
			
			b) Impaired energy production and chronic fatigue
			
		
		
			
			3) Methyl malonyl-CoA Mutase Deficiency
			
			
			c) Accumulation of methyl malonyl-CoA
			
		
		
			
			4) Methionine Synthase Deficiency
			
			
			d) Pernicious anaemia with immature red blood cells
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1-b, 2-a, 3-c, 4-d 

Explanation:

  • Adenosylcobalamin → mitochondrial energy reactions → deficiency → fatigue.

  • Methylcobalamin → homocysteine → methionine → deficiency → ↑ homocysteine.

  • Methylmalonyl-CoA mutase → converts methylmalonyl-CoA → succinyl-CoA → defect → accumulation.

  • Methionine synthase → folate/B12 pathway → deficiency → megaloblastic anemia.

Takeaway:

  • B12 has two active forms—adenosylcobalamin (energy, methylmalonate clearance) and methylcobalamin (homocysteine metabolism, DNA synthesis).
  • Defects cause fatigue, ↑ homocysteine, ↑ methylmalonyl-CoA, and megaloblastic anemia.

questions.text: Grade IV nerve injury in Sunderland classification corresponds to which type of nerve injury in Seddon’s classification?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Axonotmesis

 

Explanation:

 

Sunderland classification Seddon classification Injury
Grade I Neurapraxia Focal segmental demyelination
Grade II Axonotmesis Damaged axon with intact endoneurium
Grade III Axonotmesis Damaged axon and endoneurium with intact perineurium

Grade IV

Axonotmesis

(Option A)

Damaged axon, endoneurium, and perineurium with intact epineurium

Grade V

Neurotmesis

(Option B ruled out)

Complete nerve transection (disruption of myelin sheath, axon, endoneurium, perineurium, and epineurium)

questions.text: A 25-year-old male involved in a road traffic accident was stabilized in the field with needle decompression for severe shortness of breath, decreased breath sounds, and hyper-resonance on the right side of the chest. Upon arrival at the emergency department, he is hemodynamically stable. Which chest X-ray view is most appropriate to confirm the underlying condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Expiration Chest X-ray

Explanation:

In expiration, the lung becomes white due to air exhaled out while pneumothorax remains black. So, white lung gives a good contrast to black pneumothorax in expiration.

 

Chest X-ray in Inspiration: Chest X-rays are typically performed during the inspiration phase, which maximizes lung volume and provides a clearer view of the lung fields. During this phase, the lungs fill with air, and the air appears black on the X-ray due to its low density compared to surrounding tissues.

 

 

Chest X-ray in Expiration: Expiratory chest X-rays are utilized for assessing small pneumothoraces and suspected inhaled foreign bodies, while inspiratory chest X-rays are performed in all other cases.

Appearance During Expiration: When a foreign body obstructs the airway, air may become trapped in the lungs, preventing full exhalation. Consequently, during an expiratory X-ray, the obstructed lung appears black (due to retained air), indicating an obstruction on that particular side. A persistent black appearance in the affected lung can confirm an obstruction.

Parameter

Normal Lung

Pneumothorax

Inspiration

Black

Black

Expiration

White

Black

 

Inspiration Chest X-ray (Option A): Commonly used for general chest imaging but can miss small pneumothoraces since the lungs are fully expanded, hiding air in the pleural space.

Lateral Decubitus Chest X-ray (Option C): Most sensitive chest x-ray view for pleural effusion. 

Oblique Chest X-ray (Option D): This view can be helpful for evaluating certain thoracic structures but is not typically used to assess pneumothorax.

questions.text: A 30 y/o contact lens wearer presents with very severe eye pain, blurred vision, and discomfort in his right eye. O/E, the following corneal finding is noted. Based on the image and the clinical presentation, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Acanthamoeba Keratitis

Explanations:

  • The above clinical features and examination findings are suggestive of Acanthamoeba keratitis.

Acanthamoeba keratitis is characterized by severe pain that is often out of proportion to the clinical findings, along with features such as perineural infiltrates and, in advanced cases, ring-shaped abscesses.

  • Symptoms:
    • Blurred Vision
    • Discomfort
    • Severe Pain
  • Ring lesion indicates advanced stage of the disease.

 

Herpes Simplex Keratitis (Option A) typically presents with dendritic ulcers and less severe pain relative to Acanthamoeba keratitis.

Fungal Keratitis (Option B) usually presents with feathery-edged infiltrates and satellite lesions.

Bacterial Keratitis (Option D) typically presents with a more prominent purulent discharge and a dense, localized infiltrate.

questions.text: Focal segmental demyelination of a nerve is classified under Neurapraxia in the Seddon classification. What is the grade of the nerve injury according to the Sunderland classification?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Grade I

 

Explanation:

Classification of nerve injury:

Sunderland classification

Seddon classification

Injury

Grade I

(Option A)

Neurapraxia

Focal segmental demyelination

Grade II

(Option B ruled out)

Axonotmesis

Damaged axon with intact endoneurium

Grade III

(Option C ruled out)


 

Axonotmesis

Damaged axon and endoneurium with intact perineurium
Grade IV (option D ruled out ) Axonotmesis Only the epineurium is intact. The nerve trunk is still in continuity but internal damage is severe
Grade V Neurotemesis The nerve is divided

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is not an absolute contraindication for breast-conserving surgery (BCS)?

choices.text: Prior radiation therapy to the chest wall or breast

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Stage IIB breast cancer

Explanation:

Breast-conserving surgery (BCS), also known as lumpectomy, involves removing a breast tumor along with a small margin of surrounding healthy tissue while preserving the majority of the breast.

  • The goal is to remove the cancerous cells while maintaining the breast's appearance and function.
  • Performed for early invasive breast cancer (Stage I, IIA, IIB)
  • Absolute Contraindications for breast-conserving surgery (BCS):
    • ​​Pregnancy (Option D ruled out) because after BCS postop radiotherapy will be necessary which is not possible in case pregnancy.
    • Multicentric Disease
    • Diffuse malignant microcalcifications on mammogram suggests widespread disease, making complete excision with clear margins unlikely (Option B ruled out)
    • Prior Radiation Therapy to the Chest Wall or Breast cannot give radiation again, which is essential after BCS (Option A ruled out)
    • Extensive Positive Pathological Margins

questions.text:
A 70-year-old male presents with progressive fatigue, recurrent headaches, blurred vision, and episodes of epistaxis for the past 2 months. On examination, there is pallor and mild hepatosplenomegaly.  Labs are shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis? 


	Hb: 8.5 g/dL
	Serum protein electrophoresis: M spike in the β–γ region
	Immunofixation: IgM monoclonal protein
	Bone marrow: infiltration with small lymphocytes and plasma cells
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia

Explanation:

Diagnosis of Waldenström macroglobulinemia are:

  1. IgM monoclonal spike, which is a hallmark of WM and causes hyperviscosity syndrome (headache, blurred vision, epistaxis, retinal changes)
  2. Bone marrow: lymphoplasmacytic infiltration.
  3. Splenomegaly is common in WM but rare in classic multiple myeloma.

Multiple myeloma (Option A): Incorrect because it typically involves an M protein that is IgG or IgA, not IgM.

Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (Option B): Incorrect, as it typically doesn't present with an IgM M spike or hyperviscosity syndrome.

Monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (Option D): Incorrect, as it is a common condition with an M spike but lacks the clinical symptoms and organ damage seen in this patient.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient with HIV presents with vision loss and floaters. On examination, the patient has a CD4+ count of 40 cells/mm³. Fundoscopy reveals areas of necrosis with the following appearance. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) CMV retinitis

Explanation:

  • CMV retinitis is common in immunocompromised patients (e.g., those with AIDS and low CD4+ counts).
    • Occurs with CD4+ counts <50 cells/mm³
  • Characterised by retinal necrosis with mild vitritis, and the sauce & cheese (AKA pizza pie) appearance in fundoscopic examination.
  • Classical fundus finding: Yellow-white retinal lesions with hemorrhages along the vascular arcades, giving a “pizza pie” or “cottage cheese with ketchup” appearance.

 

Toxoplasmosis (Option A) usually causes focal necrotizing retinochoroiditis with overlying vitreous inflammation (“headlight in the fog” appearance).

Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) (Option B) can cause acute retinal necrosis but is less common in HIV and usually more peripheral with rapid progression.

Herpes Zoster Ophthalmicus (HZO) (Option D) involves the cornea and anterior segment, not characteristic retinal necrosis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female patient presents with a history of abdominal surgery performed 3 days ago. She reports worsening abdominal distension and has not passed stool since the surgery. On examination her abdomen is distended, and bowel sounds are absent. Which of the following statements is correct regarding this condition?

choices.text: X-ray shows dilated bowel loops and air-fluid levels

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) X-ray shows dilated bowel loops and air-fluid levels 

Explanation:

This presentation is consistent with Paralytic Ileus, a condition where impaired peristaltic activity results in decreased bowel motility.

  • Characterized by:
    • Impaired intestinal motility due to failure of peristaltic wave transmission.
    • Collection of food and fluid in the bowel (Option A).
    • Abdominal distension.

Etiology
  • Abdominal surgery.
  • Uremia.
  • Mesenteric ischemia.
  • Retroperitoneal hematoma.
  • Intra-abdominal sepsis.
  • Dyselectrolytemia (e.g., hypokalemia) (Option D ruled out).
  • Drugs affecting intestinal motility:
    • Opiates.
    • Antipsychotics.

Investigations

IOC: Abdominal X-ray. (Option C ruled out)

Findings:

  • Dilated bowel loops.
  • Gas in the colon and rectum.
  • Multiple air-fluid levels.

questions.text:
Match the following:

 


	
		
			
			1. Colostrum
			
			
			a. Higher in fat and sugar content
			
		
		
			
			2. Transitional Milk
			
			
			b. Higher lactose
			
		
		
			
			3. Mature Milk
			
			
			c. High in antibodies, low in lactose
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 1-c, 2-a, 3-b

 

Explanation:

Milk Type

Time of Production

Appearance

Quantity

Key Components

Colostrum

Initial 3-4 days after delivery

Yellow and thick

Small
  • High in antibodies, immune-competent cells, vitamins A, D, E, and K.
  • Rich in immunoglobulins and proteins.
  • Low in lactose.

Transitional Milk

From 3-4 days until two weeks

Thinner than colostrum

Moderate
  • Decreased immunoglobulins and proteins.
  • Increased fat and sugar.

Mature Milk

Follows transitional milk

Thinner and watery

Variable
  • Consistent in nutrient composition
  • Balanced in nutrients essential for growth
  • Higher lactose content.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman was presented with chronic cough, weight loss, and night sweats, and was initially diagnosed as pulmonary tuberculosis. She now complains of menstrual irregularities and infertility. Upon further investigation, the following radiograph is observed. What is the most likely explanation for her current condition?

choices.text: Direct extension of pulmonary TB to the uterus
Secondary genital TB due to hematogenous spread from pulmonary TB
Reactivation of latent TB in the uterus
Direct extension from peritoneum to the uterus

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Secondary genital TB due to hematogenous spread from pulmonary TB

Explanation:
This clinical scenario describes primary pulmonary TB leading secondarily to genital TB which causes complications such as Asherman’s syndrome.

  • Asherman's Syndrome is characterized by the formation of fibrous bands within the uterine cavity.
  • Endometrial ulceration due to TB uterus may lead to such adhesion or synechiae formation.
  • This may cause complications such as infertility, recurrent abortions, and secondary amenorrhea.

  • Genital TB usually spreads to the genital tract hematogenously from a primary focus, often the lungs.

Clinical Presentation:

  • Predominantly affects women of reproductive age group.
  • Primary or secondary infertility in 70-80% of cases of pelvic tuberculosis.
    • This may be due to tubal blockage/adhesions, endometrial destruction/synechiae formation, and implantation failure.
  • Menstrual abnormalities such as menorrhagia or oligomenorrhea or amenorrhea. Secondary amenorrhea is the most common presenting symptom.
  • Chronic pelvic pain
  • Tubo-ovarian mass
  • Constitutional symptoms like fever, loss of weight, malaise, anemia.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with nasal obstruction, recurrent nasal bleeding, and a mass protruding from his nasal cavity. On examination, a polypoidal, pink-colored mass with white dots on the surface is noted. It bleeds easily on touch. A biopsy is shown below. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Complete excision of the mass

 

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation and biopsy showing sporangia with spores is most consistent with rhinosporidiosis.
  • The primary treatment is the complete excision of the mass with a diathermy knife and cauterization of its base.

 

Diagnosis of rhinosporidiosis:

  • Biopsy shows several sporangia, oval or round in shape and with spores

 

 

  • Diagnosis cannot be established on culture.

 

Treatment:

Surgery: (Option D)

  • It is the primary treatment option.
  • Complete excision of the mass with a diathermy knife and cauterization of its base.
  • Recurrence is very common.

 

Medical treatment:

  • Dapsone is partially effective; it is also used post op to prevent recurrence. (Option C)


Amphotericin B (Option A): It is an antifungal, used in the treatment of fungal infections, not used in the treatment of rhinoscleroma

Cyclophosphamide (Option B):  It is a cytotoxic drug, not used in the treatment of rhinosporidiosis

questions.text: Which of the given options are correctly matched based on the image given?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 2- Fourth Ventricle, 4- Aqueduct

Explanation:

The given image shows the ventricular system of the brain

  • Lateral ventricle horns:
    • Anterior horn (5) - extends into the frontal lobe
    • Posterior horn (1) -extends into the occipital lobe
    • Inferior horn (3) - extends into the temporal lobe
  • The third ventricle (6) is a narrow space located between the two thalami.
    • It connects to the lateral ventricles to the fourth ventricle (2) in the back through the cerebral aqueduct of Sylvius (4)
  • Atrium (7)

 

Takeaway:

  • Ventricular system flow: Lateral ventricles → Foramen of Monro → 3rd ventricle → Aqueduct → 4th ventricle → subarachnoid space/central canal.

questions.text: Given below is the instrument used in a procedure done in the second stage of labor. Which is the most commonly performed type of this procedure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Mediolateral

Explanation:

Given is an image of episiotomy scissors. The most prevalent type of episiotomy is mediolateral episiotomy.

 

 

Steps of mediolateral episiotomy:

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl presents with severe headaches, vomiting, and papilloedema. Imaging reveals obstructive hydrocephalus due to a tumour blocking the exit of cerebrospinal fluid from the fourth ventricle. Which of the following structures is most likely blocked?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Foramina of Luschka
 

Explanation:

  • The foramina of Luschka and the Foramen of Magendie allow CSF to exit from the fourth ventricle into the subarachnoid space, and their obstruction can lead to hydrocephalus.

 

Foramen of Magendie and Luschka:

 

Aspect

Foramen of Magendie

(Median aperture)

Location

Caudal to the cerebellar nodule

Function

Main communication between ventricles and subarachnoid space

Associated Pathology

A blockage here would prevent CSF from exiting medially into the subarachnoid space.

 

  • The Foramen of Monro (Option A): Connects the lateral ventricles to the third ventricle, not the fourth ventricle.
  • Foramen rotundum (Option C): Transmits the maxillary nerve (V2) and is unrelated to CSF flow or the ventricular system.
  • Foramen ovale (Option D): It transmits the mandibular nerve (V3) and is not involved in CSF drainage from the fourth ventricle.

questions.text: A 5-month-old infant is brought to the pediatrician due to poor weight gain, vomiting, and yellowing of the skin and eyes. Genetic testing confirms a deficiency in fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase. The physician recommends a low-protein diet and the drug Nitisinone. Which of the following is not an indication of Nitisinone?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Tyrosinemia type II

Explanation:

  • Nitisinone inhibits 4-hydroxyphenylpyruvate dioxygenase, preventing toxic metabolite buildup in tyrosine metabolism.

  • Indications: Tyrosinemia type I, Alkaptonuria, Hawkinsinuria.

  • Tyrosinemia type II is due to tyrosine aminotransferase deficiency and is not treated with Nitisinone.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with a history of migraine presents with a 3-month history of bloody diarrhoea and tenesmus. Labs show Hb 10 gm%, CRP positive, and sigmoidoscopy showing erythema, mucosal friability starting from the rectum and extending proximally. Which of the following drugs will be started for the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Mesalamine

Explanation:

  • Mesalamine is the first-line treatment for mild to moderate ulcerative colitis, as it directly reduces mucosal inflammation and is effective in inducing and maintaining remission.
  • Other drugs used in treating mild to moderate ulcerative colitis: Budesonide, Hydrocortisone (rectal), & Oral Prednisolone

Sulphasalazine (Option A): Sulphasalazine also works but has more side effects due to its sulfapyridine component, making mesalamine the preferred choice.

Azathioprine (Option C): It is reserved for steroid-dependent or refractory cases and is not used as initial therapy.

Methylprednisolone (Option D): Used for moderate to severe flares or when patients do not respond to mesalamine, not as initial treatment.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT one of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) adopted by the United Nations in 2015?

choices.text: End poverty in all its forms everywhere
Ensure inclusive and equitable quality education for all
Promote sustainable consumption and production patterns

questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Achieve world peace and disarmament

Explanation: 

The Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), adopted by the United Nations and UNDP in 2015, aim to eradicate poverty, ensure prosperity, and protect the planet by 2030. There are 17 goals:

  1. End poverty everywhere in all its forms. (Option A ruled out)

  2. Zero hunger- Achieve food security, improve nutrition, and promote sustainable agriculture.

  3. Ensure healthy lives and well-being for all ages.

  4. Provide inclusive and equitable quality education and lifelong learning opportunities. (Option B ruled out) 

  5. Achieve gender equality and empower women and girls. 

  6. Ensure access to sustainable & clean water and sanitation for all.

  7. Ensure access to affordable, clean and modern energy for all.

  8. Promote sustainable economic growth, full employment, and decent work.

  9. Build resilient infrastructure, promote sustainable industrialization, and foster innovation.

  10. Reduce inequality within and among countries.

  11. Make cities and human settlements inclusive, safe, resilient, and sustainable

  12. Ensure sustainable consumption and production patterns. (Option C ruled out) 

  13. Take urgent action to combat climate change and its impacts. 

  14. Conserve and sustainably use water bodies - oceans, seas, and marine resources. 

  15. Protect, restore, and sustainably use terrestrial ecosystems and preserve biodiversity. 

  16. Promote peaceful and inclusive societies, ensure access to justice, and build effective institutions. 

  17. Strengthen global partnerships for sustainable development.

questions.text: A forensic team is called to investigate a case of judicial hanging in an obese individual. The victim was found suspended from a significant height with the knot positioned at the back of the neck. During the autopsy, a transverse tear in the carotid artery is observed, consistent with a long drop hanging. Which of the following findings is most likely associated with this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Amussat's Sign

Explanation:

The scenario describes the typical presentation of Amussat's Sign, which is characterized by transverse carotid artery tears, particularly in cases of long drop hangings with posteriorly placed knots, especially in obese victims.

 

  • While dribbling of saliva (Option A ruled out) and ligature marks (Option B ruled out) are significant, Amussat's Sign specifically indicates carotid artery injuries in hanging.
  • Simon's Sign indicates hemorrhages in the lumbar spine but is not directly linked to the mechanics of hanging. (Option D ruled out)

questions.text:
Match the following Socio-Economic Status (SES) scales with their respective contexts:

 


	
		
			
			A. Modified Kuppuswamy scale
			
			
			1. Non-Indian SES scale
			
		
		
			
			B. Udai Pareek scale
			
			
			2. Urban SES scale
			
		
		
			
			C. Bhardwaj scale
			
			
			3. Rural SES scale
			
		
		
			
			D. Hollingshead scale
			
			
			4. Student’s scale
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) A-2, B-3, C-4, D-1

Explanation:

Socio-economic status scales:

Urban SES scales:

  • Modified kuppuswamy scale
  • Kulshrestha scale
  • Srivastava scale
  • Jalota scale
  • Gaur’s scale

Rural SES scale:

  • Udai Pareek scale
  • Modified B.G Prasad scale
  • Rahudkar scale
  • Shirpurkar scale

Students' scale:

  • Bhardwaj scale

Non-Indian SES scales:

  • Hollingshead (occupation-based) scale
  • Henderson scale

questions.text: A 27-year-old female presents with a yellow vaginal discharge and itching. A pelvic examination revealed an erythematous cervix. A wet mount preparation is shown below. Which of the following statements is not true about this patient's condition?

choices.text: It is the most common cause of non-viral sexually transmitted diseases worldwide.
The preferred treatment is a single dose of metronidazole.
Repeat NAAT testing after 3 days is required to confirm eradication of the infection.
Sexual partners should be treated simultaneously to prevent reinfection.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Repeat NAAT testing after 3 days is required to confirm eradication of the infection.

 

Explanation:

The clinical vignette of a female with yellow vaginal discharge, pruritus, erythematous cervix and wet mount preparation showing trichomonads suggests trichomoniasis caused by Trichomonas vaginalis.

Repeat NAAT testing after 3 weeks is required only for follow-up testing for cases where symptoms persist or reinfection is suspected.

Trichomoniasis - Most common non-viral STD worldwide (Option A)

Clinical findings
  • Severe irritation and pruritus.
  • Foul, thin, greenish-yellow, frothy discharge.
  • Dysuria, dyspareunia, vulvar pruritus, and lower abdominal pain.

Diagnosis
  • Vaginal pH >4.5
  • Microscopy: motile trichomonads.
  • Colpitis macularis (strawberry vagina): subepithelial haemorrhage on cervix/vagina.
  • Lab-based NAATs for trichomonal DNA: (Option C)
    • Repeat test if suspect persisted infection/ re-infection.
    • Not distinguishing live from dead (adequately treated) trichomonas; hence, repeat testing delayed for 3 weeks.

Treatment
  • DOC: Metronidazole 500 mg (400 mg) BD for 7 days or 2 g orally once (Option B).
  • If allergy: desensitisation.
  • Treat sex partners (Option D).
  • Abstain sex and condom use.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a history of alcohol abuse presents to the clinic with difficulty in straightening his right middle finger as shown in the image below. He mentions that this has progressively worsened over the past year. Which of the following statements is false regarding the condition he may be experiencing?

choices.text: The flexion deformity primarily affects the distal interphalangeal joints of the fingers.
Thickening of the palmar aponeurosis is a key feature of this condition.
Individuals with liver cirrhosis have a higher incidence of this condition.
Observation is often sufficient for mild cases of this condition.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) The flexion deformity primarily affects the distal interphalangeal joints of the fingers.

Explanation:
In this case, the patient's presentation aligns with Dupuytren's contracture:

  1. In conditions like Dupuytren's contracture, the primary flexion deformity affects the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints, while the DIP joints are typically unaffected or less affected (Option A).
  2. Pathoanatomy involves thickening of the palmar aponeurosis (Option B).
  3. History of alcohol abuse, which may be associated with liver cirrhosis, a risk factor for Dupuytren's (Option C)
  4. Observation is often sufficient for mild cases of this condition, but in severe cases, surgical excision of the palmar aponeurosis is performed (Option D)

questions.text: Which of the following sequences correctly describes the phases of pathogenesis in Type III hypersensitivity?

choices.text: Formation of immune complexes → Inflammation and tissue injury → Deposition in blood vessels.
Deposition of immune complexes → Formation of antibodies → Tissue injury and inflammation.
Formation of immune complexes → Deposition in tissues → Inflammation and tissue injury.
Antibody production → Immune complex formation → Activation of cytotoxic T cells.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Formation of immune complexes → Deposition in tissues → Inflammation and tissue injury.

Explanation:

Phases of Type 3 hypersensitivity:

1. Formation of Immune Complexes:

  • After introducing a protein antigen, antibodies are formed (typically within one week) and react with the antigen in circulation, creating antigen-antibody complexes.

2. Deposition of Immune Complexes:

  • These complexes circulate and are deposited in blood vessels, particularly in organs like the kidneys and joints.
  • Medium-sized complexes formed in slight antigen excess are most pathogenic.

3. Inflammation and Tissue Injury:

  • Deposited immune complexes trigger acute inflammation about 10 days post-antigen exposure, leading to symptoms like fever, joint pain, and proteinuria.
  • Complement activation contributes to tissue injury, with serum C3 levels potentially serving as a marker for disease activity.

questions.text: A 28 year old pregnant woman at 37 weeks gestation presents to the obstetric clinic for a routine check-up. On abdominal examination, the fetal head is not engaged in the pelvis, and the pelvic grip is empty. Fetal heart rate monitoring shows a normal baseline with reassuring variability. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) External cephalic version

Explanation:

In the given scenario, the pregnant woman presents at 37 weeks, the fetal head is not engaged, and the fetal status is stable, which is in a transverse lie. An external cephalic version could be the appropriate next step in management to attempt to reposition the fetus for a potential vaginal delivery.

  • M/c cause of transverse lie - Prematurity
  • It has high risk of cord prolapse
  • Antenatal Management: If there are no contraindications, attempt an external cephalic version (ECV) beyond 35 weeks for the transverse lie.
  • If Version Fails or is Contraindicated: Elective cesarean section (Option D) is the preferred delivery method.
  • Management in Labor: In early labor, try an external cephalic version (ECV) if appropriate or opt for cesarean section if ECV is unsuccessful. In late labor, ECV is usually impractical due to ruptured membranes, so the cesarean section is preferred in such cases.
  • Internal Version Considerations: Only for specific cases like managing the second twin.

Immediate induction of labour (Option A): The fetal head is not engaged in the pelvis, which means the baby is not in a favourable position for a safe vaginal delivery. Attempting induction could increase the risk of complications such as cord prolapse or obstruction.

Vaginal delivery with careful monitoring (Option C): Vaginal delivery is contraindicated in transverse lie due to the risk of cord prolapse or obstructed labour.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with excessive bleeding following a tooth extraction. She reports a history of recurrent nosebleeds and easy bruising since childhood. Lab tests show prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) and normal prothrombin time (PT). Further testing reveals decreased levels of a clotting factor’s activity. Which of the following is not an intrinsic factor?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Factor VII

Explanation:

  • Factor VII is an extrinsic factor.

 

Clotting cascade:

 

 

 

Extrinsic factors

Intrinsic factors

Common pathway factors

3 (tissue factor), 7

12, 11, 9 (Options A, C , D), 8

10, 5, 2, 1, 13

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication for ICD implantation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome

 

Explanation:

  • While Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome can lead to arrhythmias, it is typically amenable to catheter ablation, making ICD implantation unnecessary in the absence of other risk factors.

Indication for ICD implantation

  • Ischemic, Non-ischemic, Hypertrophic (Option C ruled out), and Familial cardiomyopathy 
  • Arrhythmogenic right ventricular dysplasia
  • Cardiac sarcoidosis
  • Brugada syndrome
  • Long-QT syndrome (Option D ruled out)
  • Catecholaminergic polymorphic VT (CPVT)
  • LV noncompaction
  • Chagas disease (dilated cardiomyopathy due to infection) (Option A ruled out)

questions.text: IBD is usually associated with extraintestinal features. Which of the following hepatobiliary features is not seen in Patients with IBD?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: Option D) Primary biliary cholangitis

Explanation:

 

Hepatobiliary disease is seen in patients with IBD as an extraintestinal feature. Primary biliary cholangitis is not seen in IBD; rather, Primary sclerosing cholangitis is seen. 

Extraintestinal manifestations of IBD:

  • Osteoporosis (M/c)
  • Helpatobiliary manifestation- Fatty liver & Primary sclerosing cholangitis (M/c with UC, p-ANCA associated)
  • Nephrolithiasis
  • Rheumatological- Asymmetrical migratory polyarthritis, Sacroilitis, Ankylosing spondylitis & HLA B27+

questions.text: A 34-year-old presented to the OPD with complaints of a productive cough with blood in sputum and fever for 2 weeks and also has a history of loss of weight and decreased appetite. Chest X-ray shows apical nodules and sputum test was advised. Identify the causative organism, along with the fixation and staining method used.

choices.text: Mycobacterium Tuberculosis, Gram stain with heat fix fixation
Corynebacterium diphtheriae, Albert stain with methanol fixation
Streptococcus Pneumoniae, Acid fast stain with methanol fixation
Mycobacterium Tuberculosis, Acid fast stain with Heat fixation

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Mycobacterium Tuberculosis, Acid fast stain with heat fixation

 

Explanation:

  • The above clinical manifestation is most likely due to pulmonary tuberculosis, caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
  • Acid fast stain with heat fixation is preferred for sputum examination.
  • Protocol followed for the ZN stain:
    1. Carbol fuchsin is added.
    2. Heat fixation, where heat also acts as a mordant.
    3. Acid alcohol: Usually sulphuric acid is used
    4. Methylene blue (Secondary stain)

questions.text: Which of the following is an incorrect statement regarding Work Sampling as a health management technique?

choices.text: Work Sampling involves systematic observation and recording of activities at random intervals to estimate the proportion of time spent on different tasks.
Work Sampling is used for the evaluation of Doctors, Nurses, and Pharmacists.
Work Sampling helps to calculate the total project cost by evaluating the monetary benefits of health interventions.
Work Sampling is a quantitative type of health management technique.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Work Sampling helps to calculate the total project cost by evaluating the monetary benefits of health interventions.

Explanation:
Work Sampling does not involve calculating project costs or evaluating monetary benefits.

  • It is primarily used to systematically observe and record the activities of individuals at random intervals to estimate how time is allocated among various tasks, aiding in workforce management and efficiency improvement. (Option A)
  • It is used to evaluate how time is spent by healthcare providers like doctors, nurses, and pharmacists on different activities. (Option B)
  • It is a type of quantitative health management technique. (Option D)

questions.text:
Match the following:


	
		
			
			Plasma Osmolality
			
			
			Urine Osmolality
			
			
			Diagnosis
			
		
		
			
			1) Increased
			
			
			a) Increased
			
			
			i) Dehydration/water deprivation
			
		
		
			
			2) Decreased
			
			
			b) Decrease
			
			
			ii) Diabetic insipidus
			
		
		
			 
			 
			
			iii) Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 2-a-iii

Explanation:



 

Plasma Osmolality

Urine Osmolality

Diagnosis

1. Increased

Increased

Dehydration/water deprivation

2. Increased

Decreased

Diabetic insipidus

3. Decreased

Increased

Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH)



 

  • Osmolality refers to the concentration of solute per unit weight of solvent and is measured in mOsm/kg.

Normal Values:

  • Plasma Osmolality: Ranges from 285 to 295 mOsm/kg.
  • Urine Osmolality: Can reach up to 1200-1400 mOsm/kg, typically achieved by or after 1 year of age.
  • Calculation of plasma osmolality = 2 [sodium] + Glucose (mg/dl)/18 + BUN/2.8

questions.text: A 35-year-old male marathon runner presents with complaints of foot pain after long-distance runs. On examination, the foot shows a well-formed arch, and palpation reveals tenderness along the medial aspect of the foot. An X-ray confirms a normal medial longitudinal arch structure. Which of the following statements incorrectly describes the function or anatomy of the medial longitudinal arch in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Has limited mobility

 

Explanation:

  • The given image is of the medial arch
  • The medial longitudinal arch is higher and more mobile than the lateral arch, acting as a shock absorber during gait.
  • Its keystone is the head of the talus, and its main joint is the talocalcaneonavicular joint.

Takeaway:
Medial arch = high, mobile, shock absorber, talus as keystone.
Lateral arch = low, rigid, weight transmission.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents with irregular menstrual cycles, acne, and hirsutism. An ultrasound reveals multiple ovarian cysts. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)

Explanation:

Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS), also known as Stein-Leventhal syndrome, is a heterogeneous, multisystem endocrinopathy in women of reproductive age with ovarian expression of various metabolic disturbances.

Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS) diagnosis - Rotterdam criteria:
Any 2 of 3 (after excluding other causes):

1. Oligo-/anovulation

2. Hyperandrogenism (clinical/biochemical)

3. Polycystic ovaries on USG

Supporting findings: ↑ LH/FSH ratio (>2), insulin resistance (acanthosis nigricans).

 

Clinical features:

  • Usually present in young women
  • Central obesity (BMI > 30kg/cm2), waistline> 88cm.
  • Oligomenorrhea, amenorrhoea
  • Infertility
  • Hirsutism
  • Acanthosis nigricans due to insulin resistance


Endometriosis (Option B): Chronic pelvic pain + dysmenorrhea, no hyperandrogenism

Hypothyroidism (Option C) : Weight gain + menorrhagia + lethargy

Hyperprolactinemia (Option D): Galactorrhea + amenorrhea

questions.text: A 30 y/o man presents with a nose that appears curved from the front, giving it an S-shaped appearance. He reports a history of facial trauma during childhood. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Crooked nose


Explanation:

A crooked nose is characterized by a curved midline of the nasal dorsum, which may appear C-shaped or S-shaped when viewed from the front. Trauma during childhood or early life can lead to this type of nasal deformity, making it the most likely diagnosis based on the patient's presentation.

Fig: Crooked Nose

Deviated nose (Option B) involves a straight nasal midline that has shifted to one side rather than a curved or S-shaped appearance. 

Fig: Deviated Nose

 

Septal hematoma (Option C) occurs when blood collects between the cartilage and the lining of the nasal septum. This condition causes swelling inside the nose.

 

Saddle nose deformity (Option D) is characterized by a depressed nasal dorsum

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with difficulty performing fine voluntary movements of his right hand following a midbrain stroke. Neurological examination suggests involvement of pathways controlling distal limb muscles. Which of the following extra-pyramidal tracts contributes to the motor pathway?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Rubrospinal tract

 

Explanation:

  • The rubrospinal tract is part of the lateral motor pathway that controls distal muscles and fine voluntary movements, making it responsible for the deficits observed.
 

Lateral motor pathway

Medial motor pathway

Comprises of:
  • Corticospinal tract
  • Rubrospinal tract
  • Reticulospinal tract
  • Vestibulospinal tract
  • Tectospinal tract

Pathway and control
  • Terminates in the dorsolateral area of spinal gray matter and controls distal muscles
  • Terminates in ventromedial area of spinal gray matter and controls axial and proximal muscles

Function
  • Fine, skilled, voluntary motor movements
  • Maintaining erect posture

questions.text: An elderly male with a history of cigarette smoking and hypertension develops chest pain after an evening walk. The pain is relieved after lying down for a few minutes. A treadmill stress test reveals ST-segment depression. What is the most likely cause attributed to this clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Chronic Stable Angina

Explanation:

  • Chronic stable angina, or exertional angina, is a type of ischemic heart disease that occurs when the heart muscle does not receive adequate oxygen due to reduced blood flow through the coronary arteries, especially during physical exertion or emotional stress.
  • Usually lasts 5-10 minutes and resolves with rest or with the use of sublingual nitroglycerin within a few minutes.

ECG Findings:

  • Asymptomatic Phase: Normal ECG
  • Symptomatic Phase (During Angina): ST-segment depression (hallmark finding), indicating subendocardial ischemia due to insufficient blood flow to the inner layer of the heart muscle.

 

 

Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (Option A): While this condition may cause ischemia, it is not typically associated with ST-segment depression on a treadmill test.

 

Prinzmetal Angina (Option B): This type of angina typically occurs at rest, often during nighttime or early morning, and is associated with transient ST-segment elevation rather than depression.

 

Non-ST-Elevation Myocardial Infarction (NSTEMI) (Option C): While NSTEMI can present with ST-segment depression, the chest pain is more persistent and not typically relieved by rest.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with chronic liver disease is noted to have elevated blood ammonia on laboratory testing. Which of the following is least likely to result from ammonia neurotoxicity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Muscle rigidity

 

Explanation:

  • Elevated ammonia crosses the blood–brain barrier and is detoxified to glutamine in astrocytes.

    • Excess glutamine increases osmotic pressure, leading to astrocyte swelling, cerebral edema, and impaired neurotransmission.

  • Clinical features of ammonia neurotoxicity: CNS dysfunction manifests as tremors, slurred speech, drowsiness, incoordination, visual disturbances, and in severe cases, coma or death.

  • Rigidity involves extrapyramidal/motor pathways, which are not primarily affected by ammonia.

    • Muscle tone is usually preserved in hyperammonemia, helping differentiate it from conditions like Parkinsonism or tetanus.

questions.text: 30-year-old man presents with periorbital oedema. Urine examination shows massive proteinuria and hypoalbuminemia. He undergoes a kidney biopsy and Congo red staining shows apple-green birefringence under polarized light. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Amyloidosis

  • Key word is congo red staining showing apple green birefringence under polarised light for diagnosis as amyloidosis. It causes damage to glomerulus and nephrotic range proteinuria

questions.text: A 35 y/o male presents with a chronic productive cough, dyspnea, and occasional hemoptysis. A chest radiograph of the patient is given. Which investigation would be most appropriate for confirming the provisional diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Chest computed tomography (CT)

Explanation:

  • The clinical features and the presence of a “tram track sign” on the chest radiograph point to a diagnosis of Bronchiectasis.
  • Chest computed tomography (CT) is the imaging technique of choice for confirming bronchiectasis. 

 

Chest CT findings of bronchiectasis include:

  1. Airway dilation (detected as parallel “tram tracks” or cross-sectional area showing signet-ring sign).
  2. Lack of bronchial tapering
  3. Bronchial wall thickening in dilated airways
  4. Inspissated secretions (e.g., the “tree-in-bud” pattern)
  5. Cysts emanating from the bronchial wall (especially pronounced in cystic bronchiectasis).

 

Bronchiectasis - Tram track sign

X-ray

HRCT
 

Black arrows pointing to the tram track sign
 

Red arrows pointing to the tram track sign

 

 

Sputum analysis (Option A): Although sputum analysis can help identify specific pathogens responsible for infections in bronchiectasis, it does not establish the diagnosis of bronchiectasis itself.

 

Pulmonary function tests (PFTs) (Option C): PFTs are important for evaluating overall lung function; however, it is not specific to diagnosing bronchiectasis.

 

Bronchoscopy (Option D): Bronchoscopy can be useful for identifying obstructions or taking biopsies, however it is not the primary investigation for diagnosing bronchiectasis.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT an indication of expectant management of unruptured tubal pregnancy?

choices.text: The initial beta hCG level is less than 2500 IU/L
Gestation sac size less than 4 cm
No evidence of bleeding on USG

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Initial beta hCG level is less than 2500 IU/L


Explanation:
Indications for expectant management of ectopic pregnancy (only monitoring hCG levels without any interventions):

  • Initial serum hCG level is less than 1,500 IU/L and subsequent levels are decreasing.
  • Gestational sac size is less than 4 cm (Option C)
  • Absence of fetal heartbeat detected (Option B) on transvaginal ultrasound (TVS).
  • No evidence of bleeding (Option D) or rupture on transvaginal ultrasound (TVS)

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient presents with a neck mass and difficulty swallowing. On imaging, the mass is located in the area bordered by the internal jugular vein, scalenus anterior muscle, and longus colli muscle. Which lymph node group is most likely located in this area?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Level IV (Lower Jugular nodes)

 

Explanation:

Chassaignac’s triangle (bounded by the internal jugular vein, scalenus anterior, and longus colli) contains Level IV lower jugular nodes.

  • Level I: submental/submandibular nodes.
  • Level II: upper jugular (skull base to hyoid).
  • Level III: middle jugular (hyoid to cricoid).

Takeaway: Chassaignac’s triangle → Level IV nodes (important in head & neck cancers).

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with polyuria, growth failure, fair skin, blond hair, and photophobia. Slit-lamp examination reveals cystine crystals in the cornea. Which genetic mutation is most likely responsible for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) CTNS

 

Explanation:

  • The scenario is that of Cystinosis.

Cystinosis

Etiology

Mutations in the CTNS gene (Option C) (encoding the protein cystinosin, a cystine transporter) → Defect in cystinosin → Accumulation of cystine crystals in major organs (kidney, liver, eyes, brain)

Clinical Features

  • Renal: Fanconi syndrome, polyuria, polydipsia, rickets, growth failure

  • Skin/Hair: Fair skin, blond hair

  • Eyes: Photophobia, retinopathy, ↓ visual acuity

  • Other: Fever (↓ sweating), hypothyroidism, hepatosplenomegaly, delayed puberty

Diagnosis
  • Detection of cystine crystals in the cornea.
  • Confirmed by measuring increased cystine content in leukocytes.

Treatment
  • Therapy with cysteamine (converts cystine to cysteine)
  • Cysteamine eye drops for ocular involvement.

questions.text: Calculate the therapeutic index of a sedative drug whose dose-response curve, when plotted, is the same as below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: Option B) 2

Explanation:

 

In the graph given,

Median toxic dose (TD) = 200 mg

Median effective dose (ED) = 100

Effective dose in 100% population = 120

 

We know that Therapeutic index (TI)= TD50/ED50

200/100 = 2

Thus, the therapeutic index of the given sedative is 2

Clinically, the therapeutic range, which spans from the minimum effective dose to the maximum tolerated dose, is more useful.

questions.text: A 31-year-old man presents with dyspnea, orthopnea and fatigue. The radiological images are attached below. Based on the given information, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Answer: B) Calcific constrictive pericarditis

Explanation:
The radiological image shows a pericardial calcification, characteristic of Constrictive Pericarditis.

  • It is a chronic condition where the pericardium becomes thickened, fibrotic, and often calcified, leading to impaired diastolic filling of the heart. The images demonstrate a thickened and calcified pericardium, which is a hallmark of this condition.
  • Etiology: Often idiopathic, can be secondary to infection, radiation, or autoimmune diseases
  • Pathophysiology: Thickened, fibrotic, and calcified pericardium restricting cardiac filling
  • Clinical Presentation: Dyspnea, fatigue, chest pain, signs of right heart failure
  • CT Findings (IOC): 
    • Thickened pericardium (>4 mm), often calcified
    • Pericardial effusion may be present
    • Dilation of inferior vena cava and hepatic veins

 

 

Acute Pericarditis (Option A) typically presents with a thin pericardial effusion without significant pericardial calcification.

Cardiac tamponade (Option C)  can cause a pericardial effusion, but it doesn't typically present with pericardial calcification as seen in these radiological images.

Myocardial infarction (Option D) would not show the characteristic pericardial calcification seen in these radiological images.

questions.text: A 56-year-old chronic hypertensive who hasn't taken his medication in the past three days presents with an acute severe headache, blurry vision, palpitations, and diaphoresis. On examination, blood pressure is 240/140 mm Hg. Which of the following is the ideal drug of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Furosemide

Explanation :

A hypertensive emergency is defined as blood pressure more than 220/120 mm Hg. Furosemide is the drug of choice in hypertensive emergencies due to its rapid onset and potent diuretic effect, effectively reducing blood volume and controlling severe hypertension.

Diuretic Type

Uses

Thiazide - Chlorothiazide (Option B)

 

HTN (effective in low-grade HTN)

It is not for acute fluid overload but can be used as an adjunct

Carbonic Anhydrase Inhibitors - Acetazolamide (Option C)

 

Glaucoma, altitude sickness

Not for acute hypertension or fluid overload

Osmotic Diuretics - Mannitol (Option D)

Reducing intracranial pressure, acute renal failure

Thiazides, carbonic anhydrase inhibitors, and osmotic diuretics are not used in hypertensive emergencies due to their limited efficacy compared to loop diuretics.

questions.text: In the genome of the hepatitis B virus, which region codes for the marker indicating high viral replication during infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) C gene

 

Explanation:

  • High levels of HBV replication are associated with the presence of HBeAg, which is derived from the pre-core region of the C gene.

 

Replication Process of Hepatitis B Virus

 

Genes

Gene Product

Function/Description

S (Surface) (Option A)

Surface Antigen (HBsAg)
  • Encodes the surface antigen, essential for viral entry and immune response induction.
  • It is commonly detected as a marker in serological testing.

C (Core)
  • Core Antigen (HBcAg)
  • Forms the viral nucleocapsid and plays a role in genome packaging and immune evasion.
  • HBeAg
  • Secretory form of the core antigen, aids in immune tolerance, and is associated with viral replication and infectivity levels.

P (Polymerase) (Option D)

Viral Polymerase
  • Functions in reverse transcription, crucial for converting RNA intermediate back to DNA for viral replication.

X (Option B)

Regulatory Protein (HBx)
  • Involved in viral replication regulation; may play a role in oncogenesis by affecting cell growth and survival pathways.

questions.text: An 8-years-old boy presents with a 5-day history of severe sore throat, high fever, hoarseness of voice, and swollen neck. Physical examination reveals a thick greyish pseudomembrane in the throat and significant cervical lymphadenopathy. A throat swab was sent for microbiological analysis and revealed the following. Which staining technique is used to identify the causative organism in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Albert stain

 

Explanation:

The above image shows Albert stain of corynebacterium diphtheriae showing metachromatic granules.

 

Albert Stain

  • Corynebacterium diphtheriae are slender bacilli arranged in V or L shapes (Chinese letter or cuneiform appearance), characterised by metachromatic granules (polar bodies, volutin, or Babes-Ernst granules) at the poles of the bacilli
  • Volutin granules are reserves of energy for C. diphtheriae, as polymetaphosphates are stored in them.
  • 4 stains can be used for staining volutin granules:
    • Ponder's stain
    • Loeffler's Methylene Blue
    • Albert stain
    • Neisser stain

 

Gram stain (Option B): It helps identify rod-shaped Corynebacterium diphtheriae, but does not help stain the metachromatic granules.

Zeil Neelsen stain (Option C): Only stains acid-fast bacilli ans is used in TB.

Gabbet stain (Option D): It is also known as Cold Zeil Neelsen stainand it only stains acid-fast bacilli.

questions.text: In a pharmacology experiment, you observe that adding a competitive antagonist increases the EC50 without changing the maximum response. Adding a non-competitive antagonist decreases the maximum response without changing the EC50. Which of the following best describes the dose-response curve changes for these scenarios?

choices.text: Competitive antagonist shifts left, non-competitive antagonist shifts down.
Competitive antagonist shifts right, and non-competitive antagonist shifts down.
Competitive antagonist shifts down, and non-competitive antagonist shifts right.
Competitive antagonist shifts right, non-competitive antagonist shifts left.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Competitive antagonist shifts right, and non-competitive antagonist shifts down.

Explanation:

 

Competitive Antagonism

Non-Competitive Antagonism

Description

Competes with agonists for the same receptor site

Binds to a different site on the receptor, alters receptor function

Effect on Dose-Response Curve

Shifts to the right, no change in maximal response

Flattens the curve, reduces the maximal response

Reversibility

Reversible

Irreversible

Maximal Response

Unaffected

Reduced

Effective Concentration for 50% of population/ EC50 (Km)

Decreased

Unchanged

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents to the ophthalmology clinic for a routine eye examination. During the examination, his intraocular pressure (IOP) is measured at 28 mmHg in both eyes. The ophthalmologist diagnoses him with primary open-angle glaucoma. Which of the following medications is primarily designed to lower intraocular pressure by reducing the production of aqueous humor?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Acetazolamide

Explanation:

Medical management of Glaucoma
Topical drugs
  • Beta-blockers: Decrease the formation of aqueous humour.
    • Eg: Timolol, betaxolol
  • Alpha agonists: Have dual action i.e. they decrease the formation of aqueous and increase the trabecular outflow.
    • Eg: Adrenaline/epinephrine, dipivefrin, brimonidine, and apraclonidine
  • Miotics: These increase the trabecular outflow and open the angle blockage.
    • Eg: Pilocarpine (Option B ruled out)
  • Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors: These decrease the formation of aqueous.
    • Eg: Dorzolamide and Brinzolamide
  • Newer anti-glaucoma drugs:
    • Netarsudil: Increases the trabecular outflow and also decreases the aqueous production.
    • PGF2 alpha agonist: It increases the uveoscleral outflow
      • For eg- Latanoprost, bimatoprost, travoprost (Option A ruled out), tafluprost, and unoprostone isopropyl (Option D ruled out)
Systemic drugs
  • Carbonic anhydrase inhibitor
    • ​​​​​​​Eg: Acetazolamide
  • Hyperosmotic agents: These draw aqueous out of the eye

questions.text:
Match the following conditions with the most appropriate drug of choice.


	
		
			 
			
			Condition
			
			 
			
			Drug of choice
			
		
		
			
			1
			
			
			Septic shock
			
			
			i
			
			
			Epinephrine
			
		
		
			
			2
			
			
			Malignant hypertension with end-organ damage
			
			
			ii
			
			
			Dopamine
			
		
		
			
			3
			
			
			Acute decompensated heart failure with oliguria
			
			
			iii
			
			
			Fenodolpam
			
		
		
			
			4
			
			
			Cardiac arrest
			
			
			iv
			
			
			Norepinephrine
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) 1-iv, 2-iii, 3-ii, 4-i

 

Explanation:

Condition

Drug of choice

Septic shock

Norepinephrine

Malignant hypertension with end-organ damage

Fenodolpam

Acute renal failure

Dopamine

Cardiac arrest

Epinephrine

 

Norepinephrine

Fenodolpam
  • It acts on both alpha and beta receptors.
  • DOC for cardiogenic shock with hypotension.
    • Stimulates β1 receptors and increases the force of contraction of the heart.
    • Stimulates 𝛼1 receptors and causes vasoconstriction (increase in BP).
  • It is a partial D1 agonist.
  • It is a rapidly acting vasodilator that should not be used for >48 hours.
  • It can be given for control of severe hypertension (malignant hypertension with end-organ damage).

Dopamine

Epinephrine
  • It acts on D1 and D2 receptors.
  • It acts on both alpha and beta receptors except ꞵ2.
  • Dose-dependent action.
    • Acute decompensated heart failure with oliguria.
    • Cardiogenic and septic shock.
  • It acts on all receptors with a weak action on β3 receptors.
  • Uses:
    • Anaphylactic shock.
    • Brittle asthma.
    • Cardiac arrest.
    • Along with local anesthetics.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about breast cancer risk factors is true?

choices.text: The median age of breast cancer presentation is 60 years in India
The relative risk of Papillomatosis is 8-10
Relative Risk for breast cancer in 1st-degree relative is 3
Early onset of menstruation increases breast cancer risk.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Early onset of menstruation increases breast cancer risk.

Explanation:

Non-modifiable risk factors for breast cancer

  • Age: Median age at presentation is 60 years in the West(UK,USA) While it is around 48 years in low/middle-income nations such as India.(Option A ruled out)

  • Family history of breast cancer: 1 first-degree relative RR= 2 (Option C ruled out)

  •  

    Early Menarche(<12years): Increases by around 5% for each year earlier menstruation begins RR=1.19 (Option D ruled out)

  •  

    High-risk breast lesions

    • Complex fibroadenoma RR=3
    • Papillomatosis RR=3(Option B)
    • Ductal and lobular hyperplasia RR= 5
    • Lobular carcinoma in situ RR= 8-10

questions.text: A 62-year-old male on warfarin therapy for atrial fibrillation presents with uncontrolled bleeding. Laboratory tests show prolonged PT and INR. Which of the following mechanisms best explains the effect of warfarin on coagulation?

choices.text: Inhibition of Vitamin K epoxide reductase

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Inhibition of Vitamin K epoxide reductase

Explanation: 

  • Warfarin inhibits vitamin K epoxide reductase, blocking regeneration of reduced vitamin K.

  • This prevents γ-carboxylation of vitamin K–dependent factors II, VII, IX, X, and proteins C & S, leading to prolonged PT/INR.

  • Early therapy may cause a transient prothrombotic state due to rapid fall in Protein C & S.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman with a 20-year history of rheumatoid arthritis has a painless, progressively thinning area in the sclera of her left eye. The area appears as shown in the image below. Which of the following best describes the pathophysiological mechanism responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Type III hypersensitivity

Explanation:

The diagnosis in this scenario is Scleromalacia Perforans.

  • It is usually associated with long-standing rheumatoid arthritis and presents with scleral thinning, appearing bluish and without signs of inflammation.
  • The underlying cause of scleral thinning is probably ischemia because of vessel damage (Type III hypersensitivity).

 

  • Type II hypersensitivity (Option B) involves antibody-mediated cellular dysfunction or destruction.
  • Type IV hypersensitivity (Option C): Scleromalacia perforans is caused by immune complex–mediated vasculitis, not delayed-type hypersensitivity.
  • Infective etiology (Option D): Scleromalacia perforans is a sterile, autoimmune complication of systemic diseases.

questions.text: A newborn male presents with severe respiratory distress and a scaphoid abdomen. Chest X-ray reveals bowel loops in the left thoracic cavity. Immediate surgical intervention is planned to repair the diaphragmatic defect. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Bochdalek hernia

Explanation:

  • Bochdalek hernia is the most common type of congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH), accounting for about 90% of cases.
  • The clinical presentation typically includes severe respiratory distress, a scaphoid abdomen, and bowel sounds in the chest, as seen in this patient.
  • A chest X-ray often reveals bowel loops in the thoracic cavity, and immediate surgical repair is necessary. It is usually found on the left side (80%), but can also occur on the right (15%) or be bilateral (5%).

Morgagni hernia(Option B) is an anterior, usually right-sided defect, often containing colon, and is usually asymptomatic rather than causing neonatal distress.

Rolling hiatus hernia(Option C) occurs in adults when the stomach herniates beside the esophagus, causing reflux or chest pain, not bowel loops in the thorax.

Sliding hiatus hernia(Option D) is also an adult condition where the gastroesophageal junction and stomach slide into the chest, presenting with GERD, not neonatal respiratory distress

questions.text:
A 7-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with confusion and lethargy. His medical history includes cirrhosis. Physical examination reveals peripheral edema and ascites. Laboratory tests show:
Serum sodium: 128 mEq/L
Serum creatinine: 1.4 mg/dL
Total protein: 5.5 g/dL (low)
Albumin: 2.8 g/dL (low)

Which of the following best describes the type of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Hypervolemic hyponatremia

Explanation:
The patient has signs of fluid overload (edema, ascites), indicating hypervolemic hyponatremia. Cirrhosis is one of the causes of hypervolemic hyponatremia.

Causes of Hyponatremia

Hypovolemic

(Option A)
  • GI/skin losses
  • Renal losses:
    • Intake of diuretics
    • Underlying renal conditions:
      • Nephronophthisis
      • Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease
      • Cerebral salt wasting syndrome: Sodium loss through urine

Euvolemic

(Option B)
  • SIADH (syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone)
  • Glucocorticoid deficiency
  • Hypothyroidism

Hypervolemic
  • Conditions with lots of third spacing or edema
  • Total fluid in body is increasing but fluid in intravascular compartment may not be much
  • Specific conditions:
    • Cardiac failure
    • Cirrhosis of liver
    • Nephrotic syndrome
    • Hypoalbuminemia
    • Renal failure

questions.text: A 45 year old woman presents with irregular menstrual bleeding. Imaging reveals a solitary, smooth, pedunculated mass measuring 2 cm within the uterine cavity. On gross examination after surgical removal, the mass appears to be a soft, reddish, rubbery structure with a smooth surface and a narrow stalk.
