Which is the most likely diagnosis based on the given morphology?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Endometrial Polyp

Explanation:

Endometrial polyps are benign growths in the lining of the endometrium. Gross examination shows a smooth, soft, rubbery mass with a narrow stalk.

Endometriosis (Option B) is endometrial-like tissue outside the uterus. Vary in appearance depending on location and stage.

Cervical polyp (Option C) is a non-cancerous growth on the cervix, and appears as a pedunculated or sessile mass with a smooth or lobulated surface. Grossly, cervical polyps have a soft, friable consistency and reddish appearance due to increased vascularity.

Fibroid polyp (Option D) is a benign tumor in the uterus muscle layer, appearing as firm, well-circumscribed masses with a white-tan appearance on gross examination. It has a whorled appearance on the cut section due to interlacing bundles of smooth muscle cells.

Match the following Klebsiella species with the diseases they commonly cause:

			4. Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1-B, 2-D, 3-A, 4-C

Explanation:

Klebsiella Species

Disease Caused

Symptoms

Klebsiella pneumoniae

Pneumonia

Productive cough with "currant jelly" sputum, fever, chills, chest pain, difficulty breathing

 

Klebsiella oxytoca

Hemorrhagic colitis

Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis

questions.text: A 55 y/o male with poorly controlled diabetes presents with a non-healing corneal ulcer in his right eye, despite two weeks of appropriate antibiotic therapy. The ulcer shows signs of impending perforation with severe thinning of the cornea. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Increase the frequency of antibiotic eye drops.
Apply a pressure bandage and recommend strict bed rest.
Perform mechanical debridement and apply tissue adhesive glue.
Start topical steroids to reduce inflammation.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Perform mechanical debridement and apply tissue adhesive glue

Explanation: 

For impending corneal perforation, necrotic tissue is first removed (mechanical debridement), then tissue adhesive (e.g., cyanoacrylate glue) is applied to seal the thin area and prevent rupture.

  • Mechanical debridement is necessary to remove necrotic material and promote healing in a non-healing ulcer.
  • Tissue adhesive glue is indicated to prevent perforation, especially when the perforation is less than 2mm.


Increasing the frequency of antibiotic eye drops (Option A): At this stage, just increasing frequency won’t be useful.

Applying a pressure bandage and bed rest (Option B): Pressure can worsen thinning and precipitate perforation.

Topical steroids (Option D) are contraindicated as they can worsen the infection.

questions.text: For a patient of acute onset hypernatremia Na= 158 meq/L with confusion and seizures, which of the following fluids is not to be used?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Normal saline:

  • The preferred fluid for symptomatic hypernatremia the fluid of choice is 5 percent dextrose. N/2 or N/4 is dilute fluid containing more water and can be used.

questions.text: A patient presents with bone pain, fatigue and hepatosplenomegaly. Blood tests reveal anemia and thrombocytopenia. Bone marrow biopsy shows macrophages with a characteristic "wrinkled paper" appearance. Which substrate accumulates in Gaucher's disease due to the deficient enzyme activity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Glucosylceramide

 

Explanation:

  • Gaucher’s disease → deficiency of β-glucosidase (glucocerebrosidase) → accumulation of glucosylceramide.

  • Features: hepatosplenomegaly, anemia, bone pain, “wrinkled paper” macrophages.

Takeaway:
Gaucher’s = β-glucosidase deficiency → glucosylceramide accumulation.

  • Sphingomyelin (Option A) → Niemann-Pick

  • Ganglioside (Option C) → Tay-Sachs

  • Ceramide (Option D)→ Farber disease

questions.text: A 23-year-old medical student is studying molecular biology. She learns that a single tRNA molecule can recognize more than one codon for the same amino acid, because base-pairing at the third codon position is less stringent. Which of the following best explains this phenomenon?

choices.text: Inosine forming non-standard base pairs at the third codon position.
The exact matching of all three nucleotides between codon and anticodon.
Single tRNA binds only to one specific codon.
The rigid Watson-Crick base pairing at the third position of the codon.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Inosine forming non-standard base pairs at the third codon position.

Explanation:

  • Wobble phenomenon = flexibility in base-pairing at the 3rd codon position (5’ end of anticodon).

  • Inosine in the anticodon can pair with U, C, or A, allowing one tRNA to recognize multiple codons.

  • The first two codon bases follow strict Watson-Crick pairing.

  • Clinical relevance: explains the degeneracy of the genetic code and why some mutations at 3rd base are silent.

 

Takeaway:

Wobble pairing (via inosine) allows one tRNA to decode multiple codons for the same amino acid.

questions.text: A 55 year old man, a former construction worker, presents with shoulder pain and limited range of motion. His examination finding is shown below in the image and there is tenderness over the lateral aspect of his ribcage. Which muscle is most likely compromised in function, and what nerve injury could be contributing to his condition?

choices.text: Pectoralis Major; Medial pectoral nerve injury
Pectoralis Minor; Lateral pectoral nerve injury
Serratus Anterior; Long thoracic nerve injury

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Serratus Anterior; Long thoracic nerve injury

 

Explanation:

  • Serratus Anterior is essential for stabilizing the scapula and upward rotation.

  • Serratus anterior is supplied by the long thoracic nerve (C5–C7).

  • Function: protraction + upward rotation of scapula → necessary for abduction >90°.

  • Winging indicates weakness due to long thoracic nerve injury, common in repetitive overhead activities.

Pectoralis Major, Pectoralis Minor, and Subclavius (Options A, B, C) do not cause scapular winging 

  • Pectoralis Major: 

    • Functions in adduction and internal rotation of the arm.

  • Pectoralis Minor: 

    • ​​​​​​​Depresses and protracts the scapula.

  • Subclavius: 

    • ​​​​​​​Anchors and depresses the clavicle, but has minimal action on scapula positioning.

questions.text: You are required to disinfect a well using Horrock’s apparatus. The well has a diameter of 1.5 meters and a depth of 10 meters. Considering 2 grams of bleaching powder (calcium hypochlorite) is needed per cubic meter of water for effective disinfection, how much bleaching powder is required to disinfect this well?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 35 grams

Explanation:

1. Calculate the volume of the well:

  • Volume of a cylinder = π × (radius)² × height (or) V= π x (diameter/2)² x height
  • Radius = Diameter / 2 = 1.5 meters / 2 = 0.75 meters
  • Height = Depth of the well = 10 meters

Volume = π × (0.75 meters)² × 10 meters

→ Volume ≈ 3.14 × 0.5625 × 10

→ Volume ≈ 17.67 cubic meters

2. Calculate the amount of bleaching powder needed:

  • Bleaching powder required = Volume of the well × Amount of bleaching powder per cubic meter

⇒ 17.67 cubic meters × 2 grams per cubic meter

  • Bleaching powder required ≈ 35.33 grams

Rounding off, the required amount of bleaching powder is approximately 35 grams.

Match the following EEG wave types with  associated activities.

			3) Theta

			4) Delta
			
			
			iv) Light sleep, emotional stress in adults
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1 - B - iii, 2 - A - ii, 3 - D - iv, 4 - C - i

Explanation:

Type of Wave

Activity During

Beta

Alert and active thinking

Alpha

Relaxation, eyes closed

Theta

Light sleep, emotional stress in adults

Delta

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with a 3-day history of right lower quadrant pain, fever, and anorexia. His examination is significant for a palpable mass in the right lower quadrant with guarding and rebound. A CT scan demonstrates an appendiceal mass. He was admitted to the hospital and started on intravenous antibiotics. After 48 hours, his fever has resolved, and his abdominal pain has significantly improved. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Continue IV antibiotics and observe

Explanation:

  • The patient in this scenario is presenting with an appendix mass. This occurs when the inflamed appendix becomes encased in a phlegmonous mass due to the adherence of the greater omentum and loops of the small bowel.
  • When a patient presents with an appendix mass, the standard treatment is the conservative Ochsner-Sherren regimen, which prioritizes observation and a non-operative approach unless necessary.
  • Given that the patient has demonstrated significant clinical improvement after 48 hours of IV antibiotics, with the resolution of fever and improvement in abdominal pain, the most appropriate next step is to continue the conservative management with IV antibiotics and observe for further improvement. 

 

Discharge home on oral antibiotics (Option A): Too early—patient still needs inpatient IV antibiotics and observation until fully stable.

Laparoscopic appendectomy (Option C): Not preferred in appendicular mass; high risk of bowel injury due to dense adhesions.

Colonoscopy (Option D): Has no role in acute appendicitis; used only in suspected colonic pathology (e.g., carcinoma)

questions.text: A 42 y/o woman is convinced she has cancer despite normal test results and reassurance from multiple doctors. She frequently searches online for symptoms and insists that her condition has been overlooked, even though there is no clinical evidence of illness. What is the probable diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Hypochondriacal delusion

Explanation:

This patient displays an unfounded belief that she has a serious illness despite contrary medical evidence, characteristic of hypochondriacal delusions.

Types of hypochondriacal delusions: 

Delusion of infestations/parasitosis/Ekbom’s syndrome: False belief that insects are crawling under the skin.

Delusional dysmorphophobia: Fixed false belief that a body part is misshapen despite normal appearance.

Delusion of foul body odor /halitosis

 

Conversion Disorder (Option A): Neurological symptoms (e.g., paralysis, seizures) without a medical cause, typically triggered by psychological stress; symptoms are unconscious and not feigned.

Delusions of Reference (Option B): Belief that ordinary events are personally significant.

Somatic symptom disorder (Option D): Persistent physical symptoms without a clear medical cause, common in elderly. Symptoms are genuine to the patient; require validation and psychological management.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with hip pain after a fall. An X-ray of the pelvis reveals a disrupted Shenton's line as shown below. Which of the following conditions can be ruled out based on this finding?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Pelvic fracture

 

Explanation:

 

  • Pelvic fractures may occur in the same trauma setting, but they do not typically disrupt Shenton's line.
  • Shelton's line is an imaginary curved line drawn along the inferior border of the superior pubic ramus and along the medial edge of the femoral neck. A normal line forms a smooth, uninterrupted curve, indicating proper anatomical alignment.

Conditions Associated with Disruption

  • Fracture of the Neck of the Femur
  • Intertrochanteric Fracture
  • Posterior Dislocation of the Hip
  • Developmental Dysplasia of the Hip (DDH)

Shenton's Line

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a history of frequent nosebleeds and heavy menstrual periods. She reports prolonged bleeding after minor cuts and has noticed easy bruising. On physical examination, multiple small bruises are on her arms and legs. Which of the following tests is most likely to be abnormal?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Bleeding Time (BT)

 

Explanation:

  • This presentation suggests a primary hemostasis defect (platelet dysfunction or vWD).

Bleeding Time (BT):

  • Prolonged when platelet number or function is reduced → best screening test for primary hemostasis defect.

Clotting Time (CT) (Option B):

  • Measures overall clot formation (intrinsic + extrinsic); normal in isolated platelet defects. 
  • Normal CT: 8-15 mins.

Prothrombin Time (PT) (Option C):

  • Prolonged only in extrinsic pathway disorders (factor VII deficiency, warfarin therapy). 
  • Normal PT: 11-16 secs.

Activated Partial Thromboplastin Time (aPTT) (Option D):

  • Prolonged in intrinsic pathway defects (hemophilia A/B, heparin therapy). 
  • Normal aPTT: 25-30 secs.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman presents to the clinic with complaints of fishy-smelling, creamy vaginal discharge that has been ongoing for the past 2 weeks. On physical examination, the physician notes no signs of inflammation and a thin, white, homogeneous vaginal discharge. A vaginal wet mount was done which is attached below:



Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the disease?

choices.text: The causative organism is Gardnerella vaginalis.
Detection of ribosomal RNA of Gardnerella vaginalis with PCR can be used as a method of diagnosis.
Oral metronidazole is the treatment of choice given 500 mg for 7 days.
Demonstration of more than 10% of typical cells as seen in the slides is diagnostic.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Demonstration of more than 10% of typical cells as seen in the slides is diagnostic.

Explanation:

The diagnosis is bacterial vaginosis and the slide shows presence of clue cells, which are vaginal epithelial cells embedded with coccobacilli Gardnerella vaginalis. (Option A)

Presence of >20% of clue cells in total cell population is diagnostic of Bacterial vaginosis.

Bacterial Vaginosis

Diagnostic Methods

Amsel's Criteria

  • Presence of clue cells (more than 20% of the total cell population)
  • Positive whiff test
  • Vaginal pH greater than 4.5
  • Thin, white, homogeneous vaginal discharge
 

Microscopic Examination

  • Detection of clue cells in vaginal smear
 

Molecular Methods

  • Detection of ribosomal RNA of Gardnerella vaginalis using PCR (Option B)

Treatment:

First-Line Treatment

  • Oral Metronidazole: 500 mg BD for 7 days  (Option C)
  • Tinidazole 2 g orally for 3 days

Alternative Treatment

  • Clindamycin 300 mg orally BD for 7 days

questions.text: A multigravida G2P1L1 delivers a baby at 37 weeks of gestation by cesarean section. On assessment, the baby was completely cyanosed having slow and irregular breathing with a heart rate of 76 bpm, and he was showing slight flexion on stimulation along with a slight frown when stimulated by an orogastric tube. Calculate the APGAR score for the baby.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 4

 

Explanation: Completely cyanosed -0, slow and irregular breathing-1, HR of 76 bpm-1, slight flexion-1, slight frown-1 =4

APGAR score

  • The APGAR score is an objective method of evaluating the newborn’s condition.
  • It is performed at 1 minute and again at 5 minutes after birth.
  • Resuscitation must be initiated before the 1 minute score is assigned, therefore, it is not used to guide the resuscitation.
  • The components, along with scores, are,
 

0

1

2

Appearance

Completely blue or pale

The body is pink, and the extremities are blue

Completely pink

Pulse rate

Absent

<100/min

>100/min

Grimace

No response

Grimaces only

Coughs/sneezes

Activity

Limp and flaccid

Some flexion present

Flexed posture and actively moving limbs

Respiratory effort

None

Slow and irregular

Normal/strong

 

Interpretation:

  • Normal APGAR score is ≥7
  • Maximum score = 10; Minimum score = 0
  • Score for severe birth asphyxia = 0 - 3

 

Therefore, the APGAR score for the above case is 4. This indicates moderate distress at birth.

questions.text: A 58-year-old patient presents with poorly controlled hypertension despite being on multiple antihypertensive medications. The physician initiates Clonidine therapy to help manage the patient's blood pressure. Which of the following is TRUE regarding the mechanism of action of Clonidine?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Stimulates α2-adrenergic receptors.

Explanation:

 

Clonidine reduces sympathetic outflow from the CNS by agonising α2-adrenergic receptors.

 

Mechanism of action

questions.text: In which of the following conditions are these CECT findings seen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) All of the above

Explanation:

The above CECT image shows a Central Stellate Scar,  most commonly seen in Focal Nodular Hyperplasia.

  • This is because of the central feeding arteriole, which has multiple peripheral branches.
  • It can also be seen in:
    • Fibrolamellar variant of Hepatocellular carcinoma
    • Serous cystadenoma of the pancreas (Option B ruled out)
    • Renal oncocytoma ​​​​​​​(Option C ruled out)

​​​​​​​A: arterial phase B: portal phase C: magnetic resonance imaging(MRI) D: pathological examination of the resected specimen.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with irritation and redness at both eye corners, foamy discharge, and skin maceration as shown below. He also has chronic nasal discharge. Which organism is most likely causing his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Moraxella axenfeld

Explanation:

  • The presence of localized inflammation, redness, and foamy discharge confined to the angles of the eyes, along with skin maceration around these areas, points towards the diagnosis of angular conjunctivitis.
  • The most common cause is Moraxella axenfeld.
  • Infection is transmitted from the nasal cavity to the eyes via contaminated fingers or handkerchiefs.
  • Treatment: 
    • Oxytetracycline (1%) eye ointment applied 2-3 times a day for 9-14 days.
    • Zinc lotion is instilled during the day, and zinc oxide ointment at bedtime to inhibit the proteolytic enzyme and reduce maceration.

questions.text: What program is the given image a logo for?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) National family welfare program

Explanation:

The image is the logo for the National Family Welfare Program

 

Themes:

  • 2 child norms: Son or daughter → two will do
  • Spacing pregnancies: The Second child should be after 3 years of the first child
  • Universal immunization
  • Community needs-based assessment approach

questions.text: A new drug designed to lower cholesterol levels is being tested. The testing involved 1000 participants. The null hypothesis is that "the new drug does not affect cholesterol levels". After analysing the data, the researchers conclude that the drug doesn't work, but in reality, it does have a small but clinically significant effect. What type of error has occurred?

choices.text: Both Type I and Type II errors

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Type II error

Explanation:

This scenario describes a Type II error, also known as a "false negative."

  • Type II error occurs when we fail to reject a false null hypothesis.
  • In this case, a potentially beneficial drug might be overlooked.
  • Type II errors are particularly important in medical research, as they can lead to overlooking potentially beneficial treatments.
  • The power of a statistical test (1 - probability of Type II error) is crucial in designing studies to minimise this risk.

Type I error (Option A) occurs when you reject a true null hypothesis.

questions.text: A 38 y/o woman presents to a clinic seeking contraception counseling. She is a breastfeeding mother of a 3-month-old baby. She reports a history of heavy menstrual bleeding. Which of the following can be given to her?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Centchroman

 

Explanation:

Due to patient's breast feeding status and heavy menstrual bleeding, Non-hormonal contraceptive such as Centchroman is advised to the patient.

 

Centchroman (Ormeloxifene)

Brand Name

Saheli (formerly); Chhaya (currently)

Type of Contraceptive

Non-hormonal, selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM)

Mechanism of Action

Delays ovulation, alters the endometrial lining to prevent implantation

Dosage

One 30mg tablet twice a week for the first 3 months, followed by one tablet weekly thereafter

Advantages
  • Non-hormonal, minimal side effects
  • Convenient weekly dosage
  • No impact on breastfeeding
  • Protective effect against breast and endometrial cancer.

Disadvantages

Has a high failure rate attributed to low compliance with the prescribed dosing schedule.

Additional Uses

Dysfunctional uterine bleeding

Contraindications

PCOD, Thromboembolic disorders, severe liver dysfunction

Availability

Included in the National Family Welfare program, making it available free of charge at sub-centers

Combined oral contraceptive pills (Option A): COCPs are not recommended for breastfeeding mothers, especially during the first six months postpartum, as estrogen can interfere with lactation. COCPs also wouldn’t address her heavy menstrual bleeding.

 

Depot medroxyprogesterone acetate injections (Option B): DMPA can exacerbate irregular menstrual bleeding.


Progesterone-only pills (Option C): Progesterone-only pills are known for causing irregular bleeding patterns and might not be suitable for this patient.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male presents to the emergency room after ingesting kidney-shaped seeds while camping. Upon examination, he exhibits dry mouth, dilated pupils, blurred vision, flushed skin, tachycardia, hallucinations, agitation, and disorientation. What is the most appropriate antidote for this poisoning?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Physostigmine

Explanation:

The patient's symptoms suggest anticholinergic toxicity, likely due to the ingestion of Datura seeds. Physostigmine 1mg IV (hourly) is used as an antidote for datura poisoning.

 

Toxins and Antidotes

Toxicity

Antidote

Datura/anticholinergics toxicity

Physostigmine (Option B)

Opium

Naloxone (Option A ruled out)

Organophosphates

  • Atropine
  • Pralidoxime

Acetaminophen

N-acetyl-cysteine

Methanol

Fomepizole (Option D ruled out)

Benzodiazepine

Flumazenil

Cyanide

Eli Lilly Antidote Kit (3-step approach)

Pyridostigmine (Option C) also inhibits acetylcholinesterase; it does not penetrate the blood-brain barrier, making it less suitable for addressing the central nervous system effects of anticholinergic toxicity.

questions.text: A 4-year-old patient in the ICU requires sedation while on mechanical ventilation. The medical team considers using Propofol. Which of the following is a key pharmacokinetic feature of Propofol that supports its use in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Minimal hangover effects after recovery.

Explanation:

Propofol is known for its rapid onset and quick recovery, with minimal residual sedation effects after administration. This characteristic is particularly beneficial for patients in the ICU, as it facilitates timely assessment and care.

 

Pharmacokinetics of Propofol

  • Administration Route: only available for intravenous use.
  • Onset of Action: rapid onset (Option A ruled out); effects typically observed for 2–8 minutes after administration.
  • Distribution: short initial distribution half-life leads to quick awakening. (Option C ruled out)
  • Recovery: faster recovery compared to other anesthetics, minimal "hangover" effects.
  • Biotransformation: high clearance exceeding hepatic blood flow (possible extrahepatic metabolism); metabolism occurs in the liver, resulting in inactive metabolites.
  • Excretion: Primarily eliminated via urine; unaffected by end-stage kidney disease. (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presents to the clinic with lower abdominal pain and vaginal spotting. She has a history of amenorrhea for 7 weeks. On examination, she is hemodynamically stable. The physician suspects an unruptured ectopic pregnancy and advises USG evaluation with beta hCG assay. Which of the following findings is not typically seen for diagnosing an unruptured ectopic pregnancy?

choices.text: Absence of intrauterine pregnancy on Transabdominal sonography with beta hCG levels ≥ 1,500 IU/L.
Failure to double the value of β-hCG by 48 hours along with an empty uterus
Adnexal mass clearly separated from the ovary
Presence of ring-of-fire pattern on Colour Doppler TVS

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Absence of intrauterine pregnancy on Transabdominal sonography with beta hCG levels ≥ 1,500 IU/L


Explanation:
Transabdominal sonography (TAS) is less sensitive than transvaginal sonography (TVS) for early pregnancy detection.

  • The discriminatory zone for TAS is typically β-hCG ≥ 6,000 IU/L.
  • Therefore, the absence of an intrauterine pregnancy on TAS at a β-hCG level of ≥ 1,500 IU/L is not typically used for diagnosing ectopic pregnancy as it is not a reliable threshold for TAS.
  • TVS should be used for a more accurate diagnosis at a β-hCG level of ≥ 1,500 IU/L.

Findings for Diagnosing Unruptured Ectopic Pregnancy

Diagnostic Modality

Findings for Unruptured Ectopic Pregnancy

Transvaginal Sonography (TVS)
  • Absence of Intrauterine Pregnancy: No gestational sac within the uterine cavity when β-hCG ≥ 1500 IU/L.
  • Adnexal Mass: An adnexal mass clearly separate from the ovary (Blob sign) (Option C)
  • Ring-of-Fire Pattern: Increased blood flow around the ectopic mass on Color Doppler (Option D)
  • Presence of pseudo gestational sac.
  • Free fluid in the Pouch of Douglas

Transabdominal Sonography (TAS)
  • Absence of Intrauterine Pregnancy: No gestational sac when β-hCG ≥ 6,000 IU/L
  • Other features: May be visible but less sensitive than TVS for smaller masses

Beta hCG Levels
  • Failure to double the value of β-hCG in 48 hours (Option B)
  • Lower concentration of β-hCG than expected for gestational age

questions.text: What are the two active ingredients in EMLA cream?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 2.5% Lidocaine and 2.5% Prilocaine

 

Explanation:

EMLA cream contains a eutectic mixture of 2.5% lidocaine and 2.5% prilocaine, which work together to provide local anesthesia.

 

EMLA Cream: Eutectic Mixture of Local Anesthetics cream is a topical anesthetic used to numb the skin before medical procedures.

Mechanism of Action

Works by blocking sodium channels in the nerve membranes, preventing nerve impulse transmission and resulting in localized anesthesia.

Common Uses

  • Venipuncture
  • Minor surgical procedures
  • Dermatological procedures
  • Numbing before vaccinations

Onset of Action

Takes approximately 20-30 minutes to achieve effective anesthesia when applied properly.

questions.text: A 38-year-old female presents with fatigue, joint pain, and bronze skin pigmentation. Labs show a heterozygous mutation in the HFE gene. The histopathology image is shown below. Which of the following is the best screening test for this condition?

choices.text: Genetic testing for the HFE gene

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Transferrin saturation

Explanation:

  • The diagnosis in this case is hemochromatosis.
  • Transferrin saturation (TSAT) is the best screening test for hereditary hemochromatosis.

Serum ferritin (Option A) is a protein that stores iron in the body.

  • However, while serum ferritin levels can be a useful indicator, they are not as specific as transferrin saturation (TSAT) for diagnosing hemochromatosis.

In hereditary hemochromatosis, LFTs (Option C) may show abnormalities in advanced stages of the disease when iron overload has caused liver damage (e.g., elevated alanine transaminase or AST levels).

  • However, LFTs are not specific screening tests for hemochromatosis .

Genetic testing (Option D) for mutations in the HFE gene is the definitive diagnostic test for hereditary hemochromatosis .

questions.text: Which of the following options would be considered an indication for surgical intervention in Pott’s spine?

choices.text: Worsening neural complications despite conservative treatment

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) All of the above

 

Explanation:

All of them are indications for surgical intervention in cases of Pott's spine.

 

Indications for surgery in patients without neurological complications

Indications for surgery in patients with neurological complications
  • Progressive bone destruction despite ATT
  • Failure to respond to conservative therapy
  • Paravertebral abscess, when it has increased in size despite medical treatment
  • Spinal instability caused by destruction or collapse, destruction of two or more vertebrae, or kyphosis
  • Prevention of severe kyphosis in young children with extensive dorsal lesions
  • Large paraspinal abscess
  • New or worsening neural complications or lack of improvement with conservative treatment
  • Paraplegia of rapid onset or severe paraplegia
  • Late-onset paraplegia
  • Neural arch disease
  • Painful paraplegia in elderly patients
  • Spinal tumor syndrome (epidural spinal tuberculoma without osseous involvement)

questions.text: A 45-year-old male undergoes a split-thickness skin graft for a large wound on his leg. Three days postoperatively, the graft appears swollen with fluid accumulating underneath it. Which of the following complications is most likely?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Hematoma or seroma formation

 

Explanation:

  • In this scenario, the accumulation of fluid beneath the graft is indicative of hematoma or seroma formation.
  • This complication can prevent proper adherence of the graft to the wound bed, leading to graft failure if not addressed promptly.
  • Hematomas are collections of blood, while seromas are accumulations of clear fluid. Both can occur when there is inadequate hemostasis or when there is excessive movement or pressure on the graft site post-operatively.

 

Complications of Skin Grafting:

  1. Graft Failure (Option A ruled out):
    • This occurs when the graft does not survive or integrate with the recipient site, due to poor vascularization or improper placement.
    • It is not characterized by fluid accumulation beneath the graft.
    • It can be prevented by ensuring good contact between the graft and the wound bed and avoiding movement or pressure on the graft.
  2. Infection (Option C ruled out):
    • Infection typically presents with redness, warmth, and pus rather than just fluid accumulation.
    • Strict sterile techniques during surgery and the use of prophylactic antibiotics can help prevent infections.
  3. Hematoma or Seroma Formation (Option B):
    • Occur when blood or fluid collects under the graft.
    • Proper hemostasis during surgery and the use of drains can prevent this issue.
  4. Poor Cosmetic Outcome (Option D ruled out): 
    • If the graft does not match the recipient site's skin texture or thickness, or if it is not placed correctly, the cosmetic result may be unsatisfactory.
    • Careful selection of graft thickness and meticulous placement can help achieve a better aesthetic outcome.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient undergoes cardiac catheterization with simultaneous ECG recording. During the isovolumic relaxation phase, which combination of events is most accurate?

choices.text: T wave ends; ventricular pressure falls below atrial pressure; mitral valve opens
U wave begins; ventricular pressure equals aortic pressure; all valves closed
P wave starts; ventricular volume increases; tricuspid valve opens
Second heart sound occurs; ventricular pressure drops rapidly; aortic valve closes

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Second heart sound occurs; ventricular pressure drops rapidly; aortic valve closes

 

Explanation :

During the isovolumic relaxation phase:

  • It starts with S2 (closure of aortic valve).

  • All valves are closed → no blood enters or leaves.

  • Ventricular pressure falls rapidly as myocardium relaxes.

  • Ventricular volume stays unchanged since valves are shut.

 

  • T wave (Option A): Ends before isovolumic relaxation. This phase ends when LV pressure falls below LA pressure → mitral valve opens → rapid filling begins.

  • U wave (Option B): Appears after T wave, before P wave. LV pressure < aortic, valves closed, but this isn’t the unique hallmark of the phase.

  • P wave (Option C): Occurs in late diastole (atrial contraction). During isovolumic relaxation, LV volume is constant and tricuspid valve stays closed.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presents with malodorous vaginal discharge for the past week. There is no itching. On examination, there is white discharge coating the vaginal walls. Based on the clinical and microscopic findings (below), what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Bacterial Vaginosis

Explanation:

Bacterial Vaginosis is characterised by a thin, greyish-white discharge with the presence of clue cells (vaginal epithelial cells coated with bacteria).

Bacterial Vaginosis:

  • The most common cause of vaginal discharge in reproductive-age women. 
  • Caused by: Hemophilus (Gardnerella) vaginalis. Less common: Prevotella, Mobiluncus, and Bacteroides

The image below shows Normal vaginal flora and clue cells in bacterial vaginosis.

Candidiasis (Option A) typically presents with thick, white, cottage cheese-like discharge and itching.

Trichomoniasis (Option B) presents with frothy, greenish-yellow discharge and often causes itching.

Chlamydia (Option D) is often asymptomatic but can cause mucopurulent discharge and other symptoms.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old child presents with progressive bone marrow failure, short stature, and multiple congenital abnormalities. The child also has distinct skin lesions as shown below. Radiological imaging reveals the following features.

  





Which of the following is the most appropriate management strategy for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation

 

Explanation:

  • The above radiological image of absent thumb and radius, along with the history of short stature, progressive bone marrow failure, and café-au-lait macules (hypopigmented skin lesions), is suggestive of Fanconi anemia.
  • Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) is the only curative therapy for Fanconi anemia.

Inheritance

Autosomal recessive

Features

Absent thumbs, absent radius, microcephaly, renal abnormalities, short stature, café-au-lait spots

Treatment

  • Supportive care - PRBC and platelets transfusion, antibiotics for infection, oral androgens
  • Hematopoietic stem cell transplant (curative) 
  • Horse anti-thymocyte globulin, cyclosporine (contraindicated in children)

Risk of malignancy

AML, myelodysplasia, oral or liver cancer

questions.text: Which of the following vaccines can a pregnant woman receive?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Influenza

Explanation:

  • The inactivated influenza vaccine is recommended for all pregnant women in any trimester during the flu season. Live influenza vaccine is contraindicated. 
  • Others are live attenuated vaccines, which are contraindicated in pregnancy.

 

Vaccines contraindicated in pregnancy

 
  • Measles
  • Mumps
  • Rubella (Option A)
  • Varicella (Option D)
  • Smallpox
  • Zoster (Option C)

Used in high risk of contracting infection
  • Polio
  • Yellow fever
  • Influenza (Option B)
  • Rabies
  • Hepatitis B
  • Hepatitis A
  • Pneumococcus
  • Meningococcus
  • Typhoid
  • Anthrax

Not recommended
  • HPV

Recommeneded
  • Tetanus-diphtheria-acelluar pertussis

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman undergoes a caesarean section under spinal anaesthesia. During her recovery, she is monitored for potential complications associated with the anaesthesia. Which of the following is not related to spinal anaesthesia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Malignant Hyperthermia

Explanation:

  • Malignant Hyperthermia is more likely associated with general anaesthesia, not spinal anaesthesia.
  • It is primarily triggered by volatile anaesthetics (like halothane, isoflurane, and sevoflurane) and the depolarising muscle relaxant (succinylcholine).
  • It presents as tachypnea, tachycardia, muscle rigidity, hyperthermia, elevated blood pressure, and raised end-tidal CO2 levels.

 

Post-Op complications of Spinal Anesthesia

Neurological
  • Nerve injury
  • Epidural hematoma
  • Transient Neurologic Symptoms (Option A)
  • Postdural puncture headache (Option B)
  • Arachnoiditis
  • Meningitis

Cardiovascular
  • Hypotension
  • Bradycardia
  • Cardiac arrest

Other complications
  • Urinary retention (Most common)
  • Respiratory depression (Option C)
  • Backache
  • Nausea & vomiting

questions.text:
A 30-year-old man is convicted of a serious crime. As his case moves through the Indian judicial system, which of the following options is correct regarding the courts' hierarchy and their power to impose punishments?

 


	
		
			
			 
			
			
			 

			Court/Judge

			D

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) D 

Explanation:

According to the powers of the Magistrate court given in Sec. 23, BNSS, the Chief Judicial Magistrate can impose imprisonment for up to 7 years and can levy any amount of fine.

questions.text:
During the surgical excision of a pheochromocytoma, a continuous IV infusion of an alpha blocker was used to prevent the intraoperative rise of blood pressure due to catecholamine spillage into the bloodstream from the tumor. Match the alpha-blockers with their appropriate class.


	
		
			
			a. Phenoxybenzamine
			
			
			1. Alpha 1 selective
			
		
		
			
			b. Prazosin
			
			
			2. Alpha Non-selective and reversible
			
		
		
			
			c. Phentolamine
			
			
			3. Alpha 2 selective
			
		
		
			
			d. Yohimbine
			
			
			4. Alpha Non-selective and irreversible
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) a-4, b-1, c-2, d-3

Explanation:

 

Classification of Alpha-blockers based on their receptor binding:

TYPES

DRUGS

Phenoxybenzamine

Phentolamine

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents with a history of frequent fractures, bone pain, and difficulty walking. On examination, he has short stature and cranial nerve palsies. The radiograph is revealed below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Osteopetrosis

 

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation and radiography showing generalised sclerosis and a bone-within-bone appearance is suggestive of osteopetrosis.

 

Osteopetrosis/Marble bone disease:

  • Osteopetrosis is a defect in the osteoclasts.

    • Because the osteoclasts are not functioning properly, bone remodelling and bone resorption are impaired.

    • As a result, the patient ends up with brittle bones, which gives rise to this bone-in-bone appearance.

  • It has multiple inheritance patterns, including autosomal dominant, autosomal recessive, and X-linked disorders.

  • Morphologically, affected bones lack internal medullary canal leading to frequent features 

 

Osteogenesis imperfecta (Option A):

  • Osteogenesis imperfecta is a collagen defect associated with blue sclera.

Rickets (Option C):

  • Rickets is due to vitamin D deficiency.

Paget disease of the bone (Option D):

  • It can present with bone pain, deformities, and fractures, but it is very uncommon at a young age and typically occurs in older individuals.
  • It is also considered a pre-malignant condition with an increased risk of osteosarcoma.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male presents with symptoms of acute onset blurred vision, dry mouth, tachycardia, and urinary retention. His medical history is unremarkable, and he denies any recent illnesses or medication use. On examination, his pupils are dilated and unreactive to light. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Atropine poisoning

Explanation: 

Atropine poisoning (Belladonna poisoning):

  • Atropine is an anticholinergic medication that blocks the action of acetylcholine in the body by binding to muscarinic receptors.
  • In cases of overdose or poisoning, it can cause dry mouth, blurred vision, tachycardia, urinary retention, and dilated pupils, among others.
  • It is treated with physostigmine, which increases ACh levels; it can even cross the blood-brain barrier (BBB) to reverse the CNS effects of atropine poisoning.

 

Cocaine toxicity (Option A): Here the patient is hyperexcitable with tachycardia due to sympathetic discharge.  

Opioids (Option B): Here, the pupils are not dilated; rather, they are constricted or miotic. 

Benzodiazepines (Option C): Here, the hallmark feature is respiratory depression.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents to the emergency department with altered mental status, flushed skin, and tremors after starting a new antidepressant. On examination, there is hyperreflexia in the lower extremities, muscle rigidity, and clonus. Which syndrome should be considered in her case?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Serotonin Syndrome

Explanation:

The given scenario is suggestive of Serotonin Syndrome.

  • A potentially life-threatening condition resulting from excessive serotonergic activity.
  • Triggers: Use of serotonergic medications, antidepressants, drug interactions, or overdose (e.g., SSRIs, tramadol).
  • MOA: Increased serotonin synthesis, impaired metabolism, or enhanced receptor activation.
  • Symptoms: 
    • Altered mental status (e.g., agitation, confusion)
    • Autonomic instability (e.g., tachycardia, hypertension)
    • Neuromuscular signs (e.g., tremors, clonus)
    • Hyperreflexia, positive Babinski sign, muscle rigidity, and flushed skin.
  • Management: Discontinue serotonergic agents. Supportive care, including IV fluids and benzodiazepines.

 

Malignant Hyperthermia (Option A) occurs in response to certain anesthetic agents, not antidepressants, and presents during or after surgery with muscle rigidity, hyperthermia, and metabolic acidosis.

Neuroleptic Malignant Syndrome (Option C) is triggered by antipsychotics (not antidepressants), it features lead-pipe rigidity and bradyreflexia rather than clonus and hyperreflexia.

Heat Exhaustion (Option D) is caused by prolonged heat exposure, it presents with dehydration and fatigue but lacks neuromuscular signs like clonus or hyperreflexia.

questions.text: A researcher is interested in examining the prevalence of hypertension among adults in a city and wants to identify any associated risk factors such as age, diet, and physical activity at a single time. The researcher collects data from a large sample of adults in the city. Which type of study design is the researcher using in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Cross-sectional study

 

Explanation:

  • A cross-sectional study is used to determine the prevalence of a disease in a population at a specific time.
  • It is also known as a snapshot of the total population.
  • Here it is cross-sectional study because it calculates prevalence of a disease and relies on primary data, i.e., researcher collects the data himself.
  • To assess the incidence, a Cohort study (Option A) starts by determining whether risk factors are present.
  • Case-control study (Option C) determines whether an exposure is associated with an outcome. It starts with diseased and non-diseased.
  • An Ecological study (Option D) compares exposure and disease frequency in a series of populations. The unit of study is population. Ecological study uses secondary data.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with dark-coloured urine and puffiness around his eyes following a recent sore throat and skin infection. Laboratory tests show elevated serum creatinine, hematuria, and proteinuria. Renal biopsy image is given below. Which condition is most likely associated with these findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis

 

Explanation:

Pathological findings in PSGN

Grossly

Kidneys appear speckled or mottled due to numerous small haemorrhages (Flea-bitten appearance).

Light microscopy

Hypercellular glomeruli are caused by infiltration by leukocytes (neutrophils and monocytes) and the proliferation of endothelial and mesangial cells.

Electron microscope

‘Subepithelial electron-dense humps’ due to immune complex deposition beneath the epithelial cells of the glomerular basement membrane.

Immunofluorescence

Characteristic 'Starry sky appearance' by immune complex deposition.

 

 

Condition

Findings in microscopy

IgA Nephropathy (Option A)

Mesangial deposition of IgA

Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (Option B)

Mesangial & subendothelial immune deposits are seen

Alport Syndrome (Option D)

Basket Weave Appearance of GBM

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents with severe lethargy, vomiting and ataxia for 24 hours. Lab tests show metabolic acidosis, elevated lactate, and pyruvate. Genetic testing confirms pyruvate dehydrogenase complex deficiency. What is the underlying mechanism for his metabolic derangements?

choices.text: Impaired conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA.
Increased conversion of pyruvate to ribose-5-phosphate.
Reduced activity of the electron transport chain.
Inhibition of gluconeogenesis in the liver.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Impaired conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA.

Explanation:

  • The pyruvate dehydrogenase complex is responsible for the irreversible conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA, a crucial step in aerobic glucose metabolism.
  • A deficiency in this complex leads to the accumulation of pyruvate, which is then shunted towards lactate production, resulting in lactic acidosis.

  • Clinical Features:

    • Lethargy, vomiting, ataxia, neurological deficits in children

  • Lab: elevated lactate and pyruvate, metabolic acidosis

Pyruvate dehydrogenase (PDH) complex:

 

Increased conversion of pyruvate to ribose-5-phosphate (Option B): Pyruvate does not convert to ribose-5-phosphate (R-5-P), which is produced through the pentose phosphate pathway, and it does not involve the PDH complex.

Reduced activity of the electron transport chain (Option C) is a potential cause of metabolic acidosis.

Inhibition of gluconeogenesis in the liver (Option D) would result in hypoglycemia but would not explain the accumulation of lactate and pyruvate.

questions.text: Below is a graph showing the results of a screening test. If the cut-off point is reduced from point B to A, what will be its effect on this screening test?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Sensitivity increases

 

Explanation:

 

  • In a screening test, if the cut-off value that differentiates normal and diseased populations is changed from point B to point A on the curve [ie. Value reduced] the test's sensitivity will be increased [i.e. high true positives], but specificity will be reduced [high false positives].
  • If the cut-off is increased from point A to point B, sensitivity is reduced, and specificity is increased.

questions.text: A patient was admitted with chest pain, and the ECG is given in the image below. His blood report shows a troponin level of 210 ng/ml. Which of the following is less likely to be involved in managing this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: Option C) Tenecteplase

 

Explanation:

The above clinical vignette, supported by the presence of widespread T wave inversion, and V4, V5, V6, aVf shows ST depression and raised troponin levels (normal <4.5 ng/ml), is suggestive of non-ST elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI). Thrombolytics like tenecteplase will not be required in such cases.

Management of NSTEMI:

Definitive management

Anticoagulation - one of the following

  • Unfractionated heparin
  • Enoxaparin (low molecular weight heparin) (Option B)
  • Bivalirudin (direct thrombin inhibitor) (Option D)
  • Fondaparinux (factor Xa inhibitor)

questions.text: During a dermatology demonstration on the Koebner phenomenon, the professor also discusses the pseudo-Koebner phenomenon.Which of the following conditions typically shows a pseudo-Koebner response?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Warts

Explanation: Koebner phenomenon (isomorphic response): Appearance of new lesions at sites of skin trauma in diseases like psoriasis and lichen planus.
Pseudo-Koebnerization: Seen in warts (verruca vulgaris) due to autoinoculation from trauma or seeding of microorgaisms 

Types of Koebnerisation
 

Category

Cause

Examples

Images

Category 1 (True koebnerization)

Development of lesions at sites of trauma.
  • Psoriasis
  • Lichen planus (Option A)
  • Vitiligo

Psoriasis

 

Category 2 (Pseudo koebnerization)

Non-immunological and occurs due to auto-inoculation and not trauma.
  • Verruca vulgaris (warts)
  • Molluscum

Warts

 

Category 3 (Occasional koebnerization)

The phenomenon is infrequent or occurs only in specific circumstances.
  • Darier disease
  • Erythema multiforme (Option D).

Erythema multiforme

 

Category 4 (Dubious association with trauma)

Limited evidence or conflicting reports regarding the role of trauma in lesion formation.
  • Pemphigus vulgaris (Option B)
  • Lupus erythematosus

Pemphigus vulgaris

questions.text: During a forensic examination, a 25-year-old woman reports that she was raped by a colleague at a workplace event. The medical examination reveals no physical injuries but confirms non-consensual sexual intercourse. According to the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita, what is the minimum punishment the accused would face?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 10 years of rigorous imprisonment

Explanation:

According to Section 64 of the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita (BNS), the punishment for rape is a minimum of 10 years of imprisonment, which may extend to life imprisonment, along with liability to pay a fine.

 

Important BNS related to Rape offences
63 BNS
  • Definition of Rape
    • Minimum age of girl for consent for sex: 18 years
64 BNS Punishment for rape (10 years to life)
65 BNS
  • Punishment for rape in certain cases
    • Less than 16 years of girl (20 years to life)
    • Less than 12 years of girl (20 years to death)
66 BNS Causing death /vegetative state of the victim while committing rape (20 years to death)
70 BNS
  • Gang rape
    • > 18 years (20 years - life)
    • < 18 years (life imprisonment - death)
71 BNS Repeat offender (life imprisonment - death)
72 BNS Disclosure of identity of rape victim (up to 2 years)

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl presents with cyclic lower abdominal pain and increasing abdominal distension over the past several months. She has not yet had her first menstrual period. Physical examination reveals normal secondary sexual characteristics. A bulging, bluish membrane is seen at the introitus. An ultrasound reveals a large collection of fluid in the vagina and uterus. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Imperforate hymen

 

Explanation:

 

  • The patient's scenario most likely aligns with the diagnosis of Imperforate hymen.
  • The hymen generally perforates during fetal life or just after childbirth to establish a connection between the vaginal lumen and the perineum.

Hymen Type

Clinical Presentation

Treatment

Imperforate
(Option A)
  • Menarche with cyclic pain, and amenorrhea.
  • Abdominal pain.
  • Cryptomenorrhea: Menstrual blood is produced but not expelled from the body.
  • Hematocolpos: Bulging, bluish membrane at the introitus. 
  • Hematometra: Accumulation of menstrual blood in the uterus.
  • Hematosalpinx: Accumulation of blood in the fallopian tubes.
  • Differential Diagnosis: Transverse Vaginal septum -
    • Incomplete fusion of the Müllerian ducts and urogenital sinus.
    • A fibrous band of tissue at various levels (low, mid, or high) that divides the vagina horizontally.
    • Normal external genitalia; vaginal examination reveals a membrane or band within the vagina on palpation.
    • Mx: Surgical resection of the septum.
  • Incision and drainage.
  • Avoid needle aspiration, as this can lead to infection.

Microperforate (Option B)

Very small opening, which may cause menstrual irregularities or difficulty with tampon use.

Surgical incision followed by excision of the hymen.

Septate (Option D)
  • Band of tissue dividing the vaginal opening
  • Dyspareunia.
  • If one side of a septate vagina is obstructed, it can lead to mucocolpos or hematocolpos.

Excision

Cribriform (sieve)(Option C)

Multiple small openings allow for menstrual flow but often cause discomfort or difficulties with intercourse.

  

Annular
  • Menstrual irregularities.
  • Difficulty in tampon placement/ intercourse.
  

Naviculare (boatlike)

questions.text: A woman presents at 33 weeks of gestation and the umbilical artery doppler imaging shows the following finding. What is the next step of management?

choices.text: Terminate the pregnancy at 34 weeks of gestation

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Immediate termination of pregnancy

 

Explanation:

  • The umbilical artery doppler depicts reversal of end diastolic flow as waves appearing below baseline which is seen in intrauterine growth restriction. As the period of gestation has exceeded 32 weeks , the pregnancy can be terminated.
  • In case of absent end diastolic flow, the waves just touch the baseline but dont appear below it. This suggest fetal compromise, hence the pregnancy is terminated by C Section if >34 weeks.
  • Reverse end diastolic flow suggests impending fetal death , hence the pregnancy is terminated by C section if >32 weeks.

questions.text: An 8-year-old child presents with chronic nasal obstruction and recurrent otitis media. The physician performs endoscopy to evaluate adenoid hypertrophy. The endoscopic finding is given in the image. What is the grade of adenoid hypertrophy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Grade III

 

Explanation:

The endoscopic image showing adenoid tissue filling from 50-75% of the choanae corresponds to Grade III.

 

Grading of Adenoid Hypertrophy:

  • Grade I: Adenoid occupies 0-25% of the choanal space.
  • Grade II: Adenoid occupies 25-50% of the choanal space.
  • Grade III: Adenoid occupies 50-75% of the choanal space.
  • Grade IV: Adenoid occupies >75% of the choanal space.

questions.text: Where does the data point fall if the Z score equals zero in a normal distribution graph?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Exactly at the mean

Explanation:

In a normal distribution curve, the data point falls exactly on the mean if the Z score equals zero.

  • A Z-score shows how many standard deviations a data point is from the mean in a normal distribution. A score of zero means the point is at the mean, positive values indicate it is above, and negative values indicate it is below.
  • The formula for the calculation of the Z score:
    • Z = (x-μ) / σ
      • X - observed value
      • μ - mean
      • σ - standard deviation

questions.text: A 28 year old sexually active male presents with dysuria and urethral discharge which is purulent, profuse, thick and creamy. He reports having unprotected sexual intercourse with multiple partners. What is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) IM Ceftriaxone

Explanation:

Given the symptoms and risk factors, the most likely diagnosis is gonorrhoea. IM ceftriaxone, a third-generation cephalosporin antibiotic, is the recommended treatment. Ceftriaxone is typically given as a single dose, often combined with azithromycin to cover potential co-infection with Chlamydia trachomatis.

In case of chlamydia the urethral discharge is mucoid/mucopurulent.

Treatment regimens in Neisseria infection:

Treatment Regimen

Dosage/Duration

Uncomplicated Gonorrhea

Ceftriaxone 250 mg IM (intramuscular)

+

Azithromycin 1 g orally

Single dose

 

OR

Doxycycline 100 mg orally twice daily,

Erythromycin 500mg orally QDS daily

For 7 days

Note: Azithromycin is preferred if chlamydia coinfection is suspected.

Alternative Regimen

Cefixime 400 mg orally

+

Azithromycin 1 g orally

Single dose

 

OR

Doxycycline 100 mg orally twice daily

Erythromycin 500mg orally QDS daily

For 7 days

Extragenital Gonorrhea (Pharyngeal or Rectal)

Ceftriaxone 250 mg IM (intramuscular)

+

Azithromycin 1 g orally

Single dose

Single dose

OR

Doxycycline 100 mg orally twice daily

For 7 days

Oral fluconazole (Option A)  is used for treating fungal infections like vaginal candidiasis.

Intramuscular benzathine penicillin G (Option B) is used for treating syphilis, not gonorrhoea.

Oral Azithromycin (Option C) is an alternative treatment for gonorrhoea but is not the first-line treatment.

questions.text:
You are examining a high-resolution microscopic image of thyroid tissue. Which of the following depicts cells responsible for the secretion of calcitonin?

 



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) B

 

Explanation:

Parafollicular C-cells responsible for calcitonin secretion are indicated by ‘B’ in the given image.

  • Parafollicular C-cells, located between the thyroid follicles, secrete the hormone calcitonin (Hypocalcemic Hormone).

 

Follicular Cells (Option A) have a round nucleus and basophilic cytoplasm.

  • Their function is to synthesize thyroid hormones.

 

Colloid (Option C) is a gel-like substance that appears pinkish and homogeneous in the follicles and serves as a reservoir for thyroid hormones.

 

Stromal Cells (Option D) fill up spaces between the follicles and connective tissue, capillaries, and stroma.

questions.text:
Match the variants of Migraine in Column A with their characteristic clinical features in Column B:


	
		
			
			Column A
			
			
			Column B
			
		
		
			
			1. Ophthalmoplegic Migraine
			
			
			A. Associated with blindness and scintillating scotomas
			
		
		
			
			2. Cluster Headaches
			
			
			B. Retro-orbital pain in males
			
		
		
			
			3. Retinal Migraine
			
			
			C. Associated with occulomotor palsy
			
		
		
			
			4. Familial Hemiplegic Migraine
			
			
			D. Presents with hemiplegia and can be confused with stroke
			
		
		
			 
			
			E. Diagnosis often involves neuroimaging to rule out cerebrovascular accidents
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 1-C, 2-B, 3-A, 4-D

Explanation:

Ophthalmoplegic Migraine
  • Ophthalmoplegic migraine can present with neurological deficits, such as third nerve palsy, which may include symptoms like ptosis and squinting.

Cluster Headaches
  • Cluster headaches are known for their unilateral, severe pain typically located around the eye, often described as retro-orbital pain.

Retinal Migraine
  • Associated with transient vision loss or blindness due to vasospasm of the retinal arteries.
  • Symptoms such as scintillating scotomas are also present.

Familial Hemiplegic Migraine
  • Rare type of migraine that includes hemiplegia (temporary paralysis on one side of the body) as a symptom.
  • Because of this, it can easily be confused with a stroke.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer:  B) B to Y

Explanation:

 

Lead time:

questions.text: Which angiotensin II receptor blocker (ARB) is considered the most potent and has the highest affinity for the AT-1 receptor?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Candesartan

 

Explanation:

  • Candesartan is one of the most potent ARBs because of its high affinity for the AT-1 receptor.
  • It has a relatively longer plasma half-life than other ARBs (about 9 hours).
  • The recommended oral dosage of candesartan ranges from 4 to 32 mg once or twice daily.

Candesartan:

Mechanism of Action

Blocks angiotensin II receptors (AT-1), exerting its pharmacological effects.

Uses

It is commonly prescribed for various conditions, including hypertension, heart failure, and diabetic nephropathy, with off-label uses for conditions such as cerebrovascular accident (stroke), left ventricular hypertrophy, and migraines.

Side Effects

Dizziness, hypotension, hyperkalemia, cough, headache, back pain, angioedema, upper respiratory tract infections.

Specific Characteristics

Candesartan is associated with a risk of teratogenicity, evidenced by a boxed warning for fetal toxicity.

questions.text: Radiation exposure is associated with increased risk of several hematological malignancies. Which of the following is least likely to be related to radiation exposure
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) CLL

Explanation:

  • Radiation is not a risk factor for CLL.

Hematological malignancies linked to radiation:

  • Acute and chronic myeloid leukemia
  • Acute lymphoblastic leukemia
  • Non-Hodgkin leukemia

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with chronic abdominal pain, bloating, and alternating diarrhea and constipation. Following a diagnosis of Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS), which dietary approach is considered the most effective for managing her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Low FODMAP diet

Explanation:

  • A Low FODMAP diet in IBS patients involves restricting certain fermentable carbohydrates known as FODMAPs (fermentable oligosaccharides, disaccharides, monosaccharides, and polyols) that are poorly absorbed in the small intestine.
  • These FODMAPs can cause symptoms of IBS such as bloating, abdominal pain, diarrhoea, and gas due to their fermentation by gut bacteria and osmotic effects in the intestine.

Low gluten diet (Option A): Advised in Celiac sprue.

Atkins diet (Option B) & Ketogenic diet (Option C): Followed for weight loss.

questions.text: Which of the following is not classified as a vasopressor among the sympathomimetic drugs?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Dobutamine

 

Explanation:

Dobutamine is a sympathomimetic drug that primarily acts on β1 adrenergic receptors, enhancing myocardial contractility and leading to increased cardiac output. It is primarily used as an inotrope to support cardiac function in heart failure rather than as a vasopressor.

 

Vasopressors:

Selective α1 agonist

Phenylephrine

(Option C)

DOC:

  • Hypotension in aortic dissection surgeries
  • To treat hypotension as a vasopressor in spinal anesthesia
  • Mydriasis without cycloplegia

Midodrine

(Option A)

DOC: Postural hypotension

α + β receptors

Ephedrine

(Option B)

Hypotension in pregnancy.

Phenylephrine is the preferred agent for hypotension in pregnancy.

questions.text: What is the following selective media that is used to isolate and differentiate Vibrio species based on their ability to ferment sucrose?

choices.text: Thiosulfate Citrate Bile Salts Sucrose (TCBS) Agar

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Thiosulfate Citrate Bile Salts Sucrose (TCBS) Agar

 

Explanation:

  • TCBS is a selective medium that inhibits gram-positive bacteria and many gram-negative rods with bile salts and other components.
  • It differentiates Vibrio species based on their ability to ferment sucrose, with sucrose fermenters producing yellow colonies and non-fermenters producing blue-green colonies.

 

Selective Media

Media

Property

   Image    

Mannitol Salt Agar (MSA)

(Option A ruled out)
  • The high salt concentration (7.5%) inhibits most bacteria, except Staphylococcus.
  • Staphylococcus aureus ferments mannitol, producing yellow colonies with a yellow zone, while other Staphylococci and Micrococcus sp. do not ferment mannitol and produce reddish colonies.

MacConkey Agar (MAC)

(Option B ruled out)
  • MacConkey Agar (MAC) consists of peptone, lactose, agar, neutral red, and taurocholate. It selectively and differentially isolates gram-negative enteric bacilli via lactose fermentation:
  • Lactose fermenters produce pink/red colonies, and
  • Non-fermenters produce colourless/transparent colonies.

Potassium Tellurite Media

(Option D ruled out)
  • Potassium tellurite media, like potassium tellurite blood agar and Tinsdale agar, selectively isolate Corynebacterium diphtheriae by inhibiting most other bacteria. C. diphtheriae reduces tellurite, forming grey to black colonies.

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl is brought to the OPD by her parents reporting that she initially met her developmental milestones but has recently begun to lose previously acquired skills. They also mention that she has started to exhibit repetitive hand movements and difficulty with motor control. On examination, you observe that she has a characteristic hand-wringing movement and a loss of purposeful hand movements. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this child?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Rett Syndrome

 

Explanation:

The above features are suggestive of Rett syndrome.

 

Rett syndrome:

 

  • X-linked dominant (MECP2 mutation), seen in girls after 6–18 months of normal development.
  • Features: Loss of speech & hand skills, hand-wringing, gait issues, seizures, microcephaly, breathing irregularities, and severe cognitive decline.

Asperger syndrome (Option A): Normal or high intelligence with good verbal skills, but poor social interaction and restricted, repetitive behaviors.

 

Cerebral Palsy (Option C): Results in motor impairment and does not involve a period of normal development followed by skill loss.

 

ADHD (Option D): Characterized by inattention, hyperactivity, and impulsivity but does not feature the loss of acquired skills or the repetitive hand movements seen in Rett syndrome.

questions.text:
A 23-year-old male presents after a fall onto his shoulder. He complains of pain and difficulty moving the affected arm. Based on the clinical presentation and x-ray findings shown in the image, which of the following statements is true regarding the condition and its complications?




	Injury to the lateral cord of the brachial plexus is more common than medial cord
	Malunion is the most common complication
	Subclavian vessels are at more risk of injury
	Shoulder stiffness occurs as a late complication
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Statements 2, 3, and 4 are true

 

Explanation:

The X-ray shows a left clavicular fracture, and injury to the medial cord of the brachial plexus is more commonly associated with it.

 

Complications of Clavicle Fracture:

  Complications of Clavicle Fracture
Early Complications
  • Neurovascular Injury: occurs immediately from trauma or later due to callus formation affecting the Subclavian vessels (Statement 3) and the Medial cord of the brachial plexus (ulnar nerve) (Statement 1)
Late Complications
  • Malunion: Most Common complication of clavicular fracture (Statement 2)
  • Shoulder Stiffness (Statement 4): Common in older patients
  • Non-Union: Occurs in 1–15% of cases

questions.text: A 30 y/o woman at 16 weeks gestation has a history of three prior pregnancies and her last delivery was 18 months ago. Which of the following is the most appropriate Td vaccination schedule for this patient?

choices.text: 2 doses of Td vaccine, one month apart, starting immediately.
1 dose of Td vaccine around the 7th month of pregnancy.
No Td vaccine is needed for this pregnancy.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 1 dose of Td vaccine around the 7th month of pregnancy.

 

Explanation:

  • This patient is considered a multigravida because she has a history of three prior pregnancies.
  • Her last delivery was less than 3 years ago (18 months).
  • The use of Td is recommended during pregnancy to protect against maternal and neonatal tetanus & diphtheria during prenatal care.

 

Primi-gravida or multigravida with last delivery >3 years ago

2 doses of Td vaccine:

  • Td1 - Early in pregnancy, 0.5ml IM
  • Td2 - 4 weeks after Td1, 0.5ml IM

Multigravida with last delivery <3 years
(If received 2 Td doses in a pregnancy within the last 3 yrs)

Td-Booster around the 7th month of pregnancy

questions.text: An appendix specimen, whose HPE is shown below, had a 2 cm submucosal nodule identified. Electron microscopy showed numerous neurosecretory granules in the cytoplasm. Twenty-four-hour urine analysis showed an elevation of 5-hydroxy indoleacetic acid (5-HIAA). Which of the following would not be seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Bronchodilation

Explanation:

  • A submucosal nodule with neurosecretory granules on electron microscopy and elevated 5-HIAA confirms a neuroendocrine (carcinoid) tumor of the appendix, typically at the tip, and it is not associated with bronchodilation

Image showing cells arranged in the form of a rosette (cells in nests)

Image showing salt and pepper chromatin

Carcinoid tumors:

  • Derived from Argentaffin cells that secrete serotonin. It is commonly caused by neuroendocrine tumours of the midgut that metastasise to the liver. It is also seen with ovarian tumours or bronchial carcinoids. They secrete mediators like serotonin (5-hydroxytryptamine), kallikrein, bradykinin, histamine, and prostaglandins.
  • Clinical features:
    • S - Systemic fibrosis
    • H - Hepatomegaly, Heart disorders (valvular heart disorders - tricuspid regurgitation) (Option C ruled out)
    • I - Intestinal motility increases (diarrhoea, abdominal cramping) (Option B ruled out)
    • V - Vasodilation (flushing, pruritus) (Option A ruled out)
    • A - Asthma-like features - wheezing, dyspnea (bronchoconstriction) (Option D)
